require any subcontractor to submit a compliance report upon written request by
the village administrator.
   E.   If any contractor, vendor, financial institution or labor organization
contracting with the village fails to comply with the provisions of this
chapter, the village, at its option, may do any or all of the following:
      1.   Cancel, terminate or suspend the contract in whole or in part;
      2.   Declare the contractor, vendor, financial institution or labor
organization ineligible for further contracts for one calendar year;
      3.   The village administrator is hereby authorized to direct the village
attorney to initiate the prosecution of violations of this chapter to seek
penalties pursuant to section
1-4-1 of this title, and other appropriate relief, against any contractor,
vendor, financial institution, or labor organization which fails to comply with
any applicable provisions of this chapter. Fines shall be imposed for each day
that such entity shall be found to be or to have been in violation of this
chapter by a court of competent jurisdiction or by an administrative
adjudication hearing officer for the village, and each day shall be deemed a
separate offense. Penalties assessed under this chapter may be recovered from
the entity by setoff against the unpaid portion of the contract price, or by
other lawful means;
      4.   Impose such other sanctions as may be determined to be appropriate
by the village administrator pursuant to this chapter and/or the other
provisions of this code. (Ord. 2011-O-20, 10-11-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 575.
2 2. 775 ILCS 5.
1-15-4: PROGRAM(S):
It shall be the duty of the village administrator, or his designee, to develop
and maintain program(s) to achieve the village policies established in section
1-15-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 2011-O-20, 10-11-2011)
1-15-5: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter does not apply to a religious corporation, association,
educational institution or society whose primary purpose and function is
religious with respect to the employment of individuals of a particular
religion to perform work connected with the carrying on by such corporation,
association, educational institution, or society of its activities. (Ord. 2011-
O-20, 10-11-2011)
CHAPTER 16
ELECTRICITY AGGREGATION PROGRAM
SECTION:
1-16-1: Definitions
1-16-2: Aggregation Of Electrical Load
1-16-3: Opt Out Program
1-16-4: Adoption Of Plan Of Operation And Governance For The Electricity
Aggregation Program
1-16-5: Solicitation Of Bids
1-16-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
definitions:
ACT: The Illinois power agency act, 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 3855/1-92, as
may be amended from time to time.
CUSTOMER: Recipients of residential and small commercial retail electric loads
as provided in the act.
ELECTRICITY AGGREGATION PROGRAM: A program pursuant to the act for the
aggregation of residential and small commercial retail electric loads located
within the corporate limits of the village that provides customers with the
opportunity to opt out of participating in that program as provided in the act.
(Ord. 2012-O-14, 11-15-2012)
1-16-2: AGGREGATION OF ELECTRICAL LOAD:
   A.   The corporate authorities of the village are authorized to operate an
electricity aggregation program pursuant to the act and for that purpose may
solicit bids and enter into service agreements to facilitate the sale and
purchase of electricity and related services and equipment for those loads
aggregated pursuant to the electricity aggregation program as provided in the
act.
   B.   The corporate authorities of the village may exercise the authority to
operate the electricity aggregation program jointly with any other municipality
or county and, in combination with two (2) or more municipalities or counties,
may initiate a process to jointly authorize the electricity aggregation program
by a majority vote of each particular municipality or county as required by the
act. (Ord. 2012-O-14, 11-15-2012)
1-16-3: OPT OUT PROGRAM:
   A.   The electricity aggregation program shall operate as an opt out program
whereby customers who do not wish to participate in the electricity aggregation
program may opt out pursuant to the act.
   B.   The village president, or his designee, on behalf of the village, shall
fully inform residential customers and small commercial retail customers of the
village in advance, as provided in the act, that customers have the right to
opt out of the village electricity aggregation program. The disclosure provided
to the customers shall comply with the requirements of the act and shall
prominently state all charges for electricity service to be made and shall
include full disclosure of the cost to obtain service pursuant to section 16-
103 of the public utilities act 1 , how to access service, and the fact that
service under section 16-103 of the public utilities act is available to
customers without penalty if they are currently receiving service under section
16-103 of the public utilities act.
   C.   Upon notification from any customer that the customer wishes to opt out
of the electricity aggregation program, that customer shall be excluded from
the electricity aggregation program.
   D.   Except for those customers who opt out of the electricity aggregation
program pursuant to this section and the act, the electricity aggregation
program shall automatically apply for each person owning, occupying,
controlling, or using an electrical load center proposed to be aggregated in
the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 2012-O-14, 11-15-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
1-16-4: ADOPTION OF PLAN OF OPERATION AND GOVERNANCE FOR THE ELECTRICITY
AGGREGATION PROGRAM:
   A.   The corporate authorities of the village, with the assistance from the
Illinois power agency as required pursuant to the act, shall develop and
approve a plan of operation and governance for the electricity aggregation
program.
   B.   Before adopting the plan of operation and governance required under
this section and the act, the corporate authorities shall hold at least two (2)
public hearings on the proposed plan. Before the first public hearing, the
corporate authorities shall publish notice of the hearings once a week for two
(2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. The
notice shall summarize the plan of operation and governance and state the date,
time, and location of each hearing.
   C.   The plan of operation and governance for the village's electricity
aggregation program shall:
      1.   Provide for universal access to all applicable residential customers
and equitable treatment of applicable residential customers,
      2.   Describe demand management and energy efficiency services to be
provided to each class of customers, and
      3.   Meet any requirements established by law concerning aggregated
service offered pursuant to the act. (Ord. 2012-O-14, 11-15-2012)
1-16-5: SOLICITATION OF BIDS:
The process for soliciting bids for electricity and other related services and
awarding proposed agreements for the purchase of electricity and other related
services for the electricity aggregation program shall be conducted pursuant to
the act. (Ord. 2012-O-14, 11-15-2012)
CHAPTER 17
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM
SECTION:
1-17-1: Establishment Of Administrative Adjudication System And Code Hearing
Department
1-17-2: Purpose
1-17-3: Jurisdiction
1-17-4: Administrative Hearings Supervisor
1-17-5: Appointment Of Hearing Officer
1-17-6: Fines And Penalties
1-17-7: Remedial Hearing Date May Be Required
1-17-8:    Remote Or Virtual Hearings
1-17-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM AND CODE HEARING
DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Pursuant to the home rule authority of the Village 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1, et seq.,
of the Illinois Municipal Code, and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3
of the Illinois Vehicle Code, there is hereby established a "Code Hearing
Department" as an administrative adjudication system for the Village of Lake
Barrington ("the Village") (hereinafter, "the Code Hearing Department").
Pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement, the Village's Code Hearing
Department and administrative adjudication system as established herein may be
one which is within a currently existing agency, such as by utilizing the
system of administrative adjudication and Code Hearing Department of another
municipality. The Village's administrative adjudication system will authorize a
Hearing Officer to conduct adjudicatory hearings of cases initiated by Village
departments. For purposes of this and related sections of this Code, the terms
herein shall have the same meaning as ascribed by the Illinois Municipal Code.
   B.   The Village adopts the foregoing sections of the Illinois Compiled
Statutes as they may be amended from time to time. In the event of a conflict
between said statutes and this chapter, this chapter shall prevail pursuant to
the home rule authority of the Village.
   C.   The adoption of this chapter does not preclude the Village from using
other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 2018-O-10,
6-6-2018)
1-17-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the administrative adjudication system of charges of Code
violations is to provide a procedure by which charges of Code violations can be
equitably and efficiently adjudicated administratively by an Administrative
Hearing Officer. (Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
1-17-3: JURISDICTION:
Those matters subject to the administrative adjudication system provided for by
this chapter are charges of violation of any regulation of the Village, so long
as the relief sought is not a penalty of incarceration or a total fine in
excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), excluding allowable costs. The
fifty thousand dollar ($50,000.00) limitation shall not apply to those cases
brought to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the
Village. In addition, the administrative adjudication system shall have
jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising out of any provisions of this Code
or other Municipal ordinance, except any offense that is a traffic regulation
governing the movement of vehicles and except for any offense or similar local
ordinance which is a reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code. (Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
1-17-4: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS SUPERVISOR:
There is hereby established the Department of Administrative Hearings. That
department shall be directed by an Administrative Hearings Supervisor, who
shall be the Village Administrator, or his designee. The Administrative
Hearings Supervisor's function is to expedite the prosecution and/or correction
of Code violations subject to the jurisdiction of the administrative
adjudication system. The Administrative Hearings Supervisor is authorized to
manage the administrative adjudication process in the manner provided for in
this chapter, which shall include determining the qualifications of
Administrative Hearing Officers, appointing Administrative Hearing Officers,
and establishing such rules and regulations, as may be necessary for the
effective operation of the administrative adjudication system. The Village
Administrator may also appoint other persons to assist with the administrative
adjudication system provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
1-17-5: APPOINTMENT OF HEARING OFFICER:
The Village Administrator shall appoint a qualified attorney as the Village
Administrative Hearing Officer ("the Hearing Officer"), in accordance with 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., of the Illinois Municipal Code.
Pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement, an Administrative Hearing Officer
appointed by another municipality may also be appointed by the Village
President as the Hearing Officer for the Village. (Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
1-17-6: FINES AND PENALTIES:
   A.   The fines and penalties applicable to notices of violations issued
through the Code Hearing Department/administrative adjudication system and
matters heard by the Hearing Officer shall be as set forth in sections
1-4-1 and
1-10-7 of this title. Unless waived by the Hearing Officer, at his or her sole
discretion for good cause shown, costs as determined by the Hearing Officer at
his or her sole discretion, and/or a late charge as may be established by the
Village Board from time to time, shall be added to any fine(s) and/or other
applicable charge(s) imposed by the Hearing Officer which are not paid within
forty five (45) days after a copy of the Hearing Officer's order, decision and
a notice of liability has been served in person or by regular U.S. mail on the
defendant, but such late payment charge shall not be applicable in the event
that: 1) the defendant files a timely complaint for administrative review in
the Circuit Court, or 2) if the notice of liability against the defendant is
vacated by the Hearing Officer or the Circuit Court.
   B.   As part of the disposition of any notice of violation, the Hearing
Officer shall be authorized to enter an order of supervision and, in addition
to other applicable penalties and charges, may order the defendant to perform
community service and/or to participate in remedial classes or counseling.
(Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
   C.   Except with respect to the applicable minimum fines specified for Code
violation(s) for certain parking and compliance violation(s) as specified in
section
1-10-7 of this title, the Hearing Officer shall have the authority to suspend
the minimum fines otherwise applicable to any violation of this Code or of any
other Village ordinance. (Ord. 2018-O-10, 6-6-2018)
1-17-7: REMEDIAL HEARING DATE MAY BE REQUIRED:
Notwithstanding any provisions of this Code to the contrary by which the
prehearing settlement of a citation or notice to appear or a notice of
violation ("initial charging document") is authorized, any enforcement officer
or agent of the Village may provide on the initial charging document that the
appearance of the defendant at an administrative hearing or in court shall be
required if such enforcement officer or agent of the Village reasonably
believes, based upon one or more prior offenses of the same or similar nature
or other circumstances, that the defendant's appearance is necessary and should
be required to assure that the defendant thereafter takes appropriate remedial
measures to comply with the applicable provisions of this Code or of any other
applicable ordinance(s) of the Village. (Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
1-17-8: REMOTE OR VIRTUAL HEARINGS:
   A.   Attendance: At the direction of the Village President, or at the
discretion of the Village of Lake Barrington Hearing Officer, in-person
attendance at any Village of Lake Barrington Administrative Adjudication
hearing by any respondent(s) and/or defendant(s), by any Village officer(s),
employee(s), and/or agent(s), by any witnesses, and/or by the Village Hearing
Officer shall not be required when and if such person(s) participate
electronically in such hearing, and the virtual or remote participation of all
parties shall be by use of a telephone conference call and/or by an audio/video
conferencing or meeting platform.
   B.   Testimony: Any testimony may be taken under oath by means of such a
conference call or by means of such an audio-video remote platform.
   C.   Oaths: Any oaths of those testifying may be administered virtually or
remotely to witnesses by the Hearing Officer, documents may be executed by any
parties to the Administrative Adjudication proceeding electronically by the
transmission of a fax or of a PDF of a signed document, which, when transmitted
to or from the Hearing Officer, shall be deemed original document(s) for all
purposes.
   D.   Evidence: Evidence may be presented at any hearing by PDF or by video.
A PDF copy of any documents proposed to be submitted as evidence at a virtual
or remote Administrative Adjudication hearing shall be emailed to the Hearing
Officer for the Village at an email address provided by the Village not less
than twenty four (24) hours prior to the scheduled and/or continued date and
time of such hearing, although the Hearing Officer, at his or her discretion,
may reduce this timing where the interests of justice, fairness, and/or equity
so require.
(Ord. 2020-O-16, 8-4-2020)
CHAPTER 18
VILLAGE WEBSITE AND SOCIAL MEDIA USE POLICY
SECTION:
1-18-1: Mission Statement
1-18-2: Purpose
1-18-3: General Policy
1-18-4: Comment Policy
1-18-5: Website Administration
1-18-6: Website Utilization Categories
1-18-7: Website Content And Content Restrictions
1-18-8: Access Policy
1-18-1: MISSION STATEMENT:
The Village website is www.lakebarrington.org. The goal of the Village website
of the Village of Lake Barrington, and the Village's use of social networking
sites such as Facebook and Twitter is to provide Village residents, local
businesses and the public with information about the Village of Lake Barrington
(hereinafter referred to as the "Village" or "Lake Barrington"), Lake County,
Illinois, other units of local government, the community and special programs
and events that serve to strengthen Lake Barrington's identity as "an oasis of
gracious living where business may grow and prosper". This chapter may be
referred to as the VILLAGE WEBSITE AND SOCIAL MEDIA USE POLICY. (Ord. 2017-O-
16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-2: PURPOSE:
   A.   The purpose of this chapter and the policies established herein is to
provide guidelines for the operation, maintenance, and utilization of the
Village website as a form of "governmental speech", and to describe its purpose
and use by the Village, as well as to implement policies and regulations
relative to the establishment and use by the Village of Lake Barrington of
various social media sites on behalf of the Village:
      1.   Village Website: The Village website is a government website, and
the Village is not required to provide on its website links to other websites
that are not government-sponsored. The Village website is committed to
providing website links that assist Village residents, local businesses, and
the public to learn more about programs and services offered by the Village and
other related units of local government, and community offerings and events
sponsored by qualifying charitable, civic, or governmental organizations which
seek to strengthen and enhance certain aspects of the community in accordance
with the mission statement (hereinafter referred to as "qualifying
organizations").
      2.   Social Media Sites:
         a.   The Village has an overriding interest and expectation in
determining what is "spoken" on behalf of the Village on its official Village
social media sites. In that regard, the Village has also established this
policy in order to implement policies and regulations relative to the
establishment and use by the Village of Lake Barrington of various social media
sites on behalf of the Village, including but not limited to "Facebook" and
"Twitter", as a means of conveying information from the Village and/or about
the Village to Village residents and other interested members of the general
public utilizing expanding methods of communication.
         b.   For purposes of this policy, the term "social media" shall be
understood to be content created by individuals, using accessible, expandable,
and upgradable publishing technologies, through and on the internet. Examples
of current social media tools include Facebook, web blogs, Viddler, RSS,
YouTube, Twitter, FourSquare, Vine and Flickr. For purpose of this policy, the
term "comments" includes information, articles, pictures, videos or any other
form of communicative content posted on a Village social media site.
      3.   Objectives:
         a.   To serve as an on-going source of Village information in the form
of governmental speech for the residents and businesses of Lake Barrington and
to enhance community understanding of the services provided by the Village.
         b.   To increase public knowledge of the functions and
responsibilities of Village government, and of the respective functions of its
Village Board (the terms "Village Board" and "Corporate Authorities" shall mean
and refer to the President and Board of Trustees of the Village), its elected
and appointed officials, operating departments, and advisory boards,
commissions and committees.
         c.   To serve as an emergency information center, providing notice and
updated information on local emergency situations related to such matters as
weather, hazardous spills, water system status, crime, etc.
         d.   To strengthen community identity and involvement by announcing
and/or providing links to audio and/or video coverage of Village meetings,
local events and activities and highlighting local businesses and
organizations.
         e.   To supplement the ongoing communications between the Village and
its residents.
         f.   To provide information of general interest to Village residents,
resident businesses, and the general public relative to Village programs,
services, activities, initiatives or areas of responsibility.
         g.   To act as a resource to the public for useful information about
the community as well as directional information (maps, etc.), directories of
services provided, notices of all public meetings and programs, etc. (Ord.
2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-3: GENERAL POLICY:
   A.   The Village website, www.lakebarrington.org, shall remain the Village's
primary and predominant internet presence.
   B.   The Village's use of social media tools falls generally into the
following categories:
      1.   As a channel for disseminating time-sensitive information as quickly
as possible (example: emergency information);
      2.   As marketing/promotional channels which increase the Village's
ability to broadcast its messages to the widest possible audience.
   C.   The Village Administrator, or his or her designee, is responsible for
the establishment and maintenance of any official social media site on behalf
of the Village, the approval of which is and shall be subject to the prior
written approval of the Village Administrator, who is also sometimes referred
to herein as the "Village web coordinator". Wherever in this chapter a
reference is made to the duties and responsibilities and authority of the
Village web coordinator, the use of this term shall mean that the role and work
of such Village web coordinator shall be undertaken, in each instance, pursuant
to either general or specific consultation with the Village Board member in
charge of communication.
   D.   All social media sites established on behalf of the Village shall be
administered and the content of each such site approved in writing in advance
by the Village Administrator and/or his or her designee.
   E.   Each and all social media sites established on behalf of the Village
shall include a clear statement that such site is maintained by the Village and
that the user thereof agrees to accept and comply with the Village's policy as
established herein.
   F.   For the purpose of this chapter, the term "local community" shall mean
"contemporary community standards as viewed and perceived by a reasonable
person". (Ord. 2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-4: COMMENT POLICY:
   A.   As a public entity the Village must comply with certain standards to
serve all of its constituents in a civil and unbiased manner.
   B.   The Village's website and social media sites shall be considered
limited public forums and, as such, the Village reserves the right to restrict
or remove any content thereon that is deemed in violation of this policy
established herein, the policies of any particular site used by the Village, or
any applicable law.
   C.   Comments containing any of the following shall be and are considered
inappropriate forms of content and shall not be permitted to be posted on the
Village website and/or social media sites and are subject to immediate removal
and/or restriction by the Village web coordinator or his or her designee based
upon local community standards:
      1.   Comments not related to the original topic posted on said site,
including random or unintelligible comments;
      2.   Profane, obscene, violent, or pornographic comments, content and/or
language;
      3.   Content that promotes, fosters or perpetuates discrimination on the
basis of race, creed, color, age, religion, gender, marital status, status with
regard to public assistance, national origin, physical or mental disability,
sexual orientation, or any other protected status;
      4.   Defamatory or personal attacks;
      5.   Threats to any person or organization;
      6.   Comments in support of, or in opposition to, any political campaigns
or ballot measures;
      7.   Solicitation of commerce, including but not limited to advertising
of any business or product for sale;
      8.   Conduct in violation of any Federal, State or local law;
      9.   Encouragement of illegal activity;
      10.   Information that may tend to compromise the safety or security of
the public or public systems; or
      11.   Content that violates a legal ownership interest, such as a
copyright, of any party;
      12.   Content or posts that contain external links to other sites for the
purpose of spam, viruses, link-baits, click-throughs, or other deceptive
practices.
   D.   The Village reserves the right to report any violation of applicable
laws to the appropriate law enforcement agencies and other authorities that
have applicable jurisdiction.
   E.   A comment posted by a member of the public on any Village social media
site is the opinion of the commentator or poster only, and publication of a
comment does not imply endorsement of, or agreement by, the Village, nor do
such comments necessarily reflect the opinions or policies of the Village, its
officers, Trustees, employees, agents, or appointees.
   F.   The Village reserves the right to deny access to Village social media
sites for any person or entity that violates this policy, at any time and
without prior notice.
   G.   Neither the Village of Lake Barrington nor its elected and appointed
officials, officers, employees, or agents endorse, recommend, or offer any
opinions on the goods or services provided by any businesses or organizations
posting on or linked to its Village website or to any Village social media site
(s), and this disclaimer shall be posted on the Village website and on each
Village social media site.
   H.   Employees representing the Village via social media outlets are and
shall be required to conduct themselves at all times as professional
representatives of the Village.
      1.   Employees of the Village are not permitted to use Village- branded
social media outlets to influence or affect the results of any election or
nomination.
      2.   When a Village employee responds to a comment, in his/her capacity
as a Village employee, the employee's name and title should be made available
as part of the comment or post, when possible.
      3.   Employees of the Village shall not share personal information about
himself or herself, or other Village employees, elected officials, appointed
board or commission members, or candidates for such positions.
      4.   Employees of the Village are and shall be prohibited from posting
any privileged or confidential information.
      5.   Employees of the Village are and shall be prohibited from posting
any information related to any commercial product, business, venture,
partnership or other entity in which such employee holds an interest, for the
purpose of selling or promoting such interest.
   I.   All comments posted to any Village social media site(s) are bound by
those particular site's rules, regulations, rights, and responsibilities, and
the Village reserves the right to report any violation of those rules,
regulations, rights and responsibilities to the social media site with the
intent of that site to take appropriate and reasonable responsive action. (Ord.
2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-5: WEBSITE ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   The Village website is owned, operated and regulated by the Village and
is an operating branch of the Village Administrator's Office. The Village
Administrator, or his or her designee, acting as the Village web coordinator,
shall work in consultation with the Village Board member in charge of
communication and shall be responsible for posting on the Village website
Village meeting dates and other Village-sponsored activities and program
schedules, which are established based on direction from the Corporate
Authorities of the Village and/or the Village Administrator and in accordance
with this chapter. It is the responsibility of the web coordinator to
coordinate and manage the Village website, exercising professional judgment in
administering policies set forth by the Corporate Authorities, and determining
what information and/or other website links shall be posted on the Village
website. No Village department, division, or official entity governed by the
Village may establish a website on the internet, for or on behalf of itself or
the Village, that is independent from the Village's primary website without the
express permission of the Village Administrator, or his or her designee, but
decisions on matters of policy and website posting, shall be consistent with
local community standards as determined by the Village web coordinator but may
be reviewed from time to time by the Corporate Authorities as said Corporate
Authorities determine to be necessary or appropriate generally and/or to the
specific circumstances.
   B.   The web coordinator is also responsible for reviewing requests from
Village officials, Village staff, other persons and other organizations to
utilize the Village website to provide information pertinent to the Village and
to the community as a whole. The web coordinator is responsible for determining
the appropriateness of the content of the Village website and all information
posted on and/or linked to the Village website, based on the policies and
procedures established herein or as amended from time to time by the Corporate
Authorities. If the request for posting information and/or a website link is
denied by the web coordinator, the applicant may appeal the denial to the
Village Board within ten (10) business days of the denial. Denial of a
submittal for posting to the Village website shall be in writing, shall be sent
to the applicant by regular mail, shall state the reason for the denial, and
may, if appropriate, offer recommendation(s) for modifying the content of the
submittal to qualify for posting on the Village website. The appeal of such
denial shall also be in writing and shall state the basis for the appeal, and
shall be submitted to the Village Administrator. The Village Administrator may
present said appeal to the Village Board who shall consider the appeal at its
next regularly scheduled meeting, or at a special meeting, if the Village
President determines that this is required by the nature of the matter being
appealed. The party appealing may also appear before the Board to present its
appeal and the web coordinator or other applicable Village representatives may
be given the opportunity at that same time to respond to the appeal in person
or in writing.
   C.   The Village Administrator is directly responsible to the Corporate
Authorities of the Village for the efficient, effective, and responsive
operation of the Village website. As the elected officials of the Village, the
Corporate Authorities of the Village retain final authority for establishing
the overall policies and procedures related to the operation of the Village
website.
   D.   The Village website will provide information to Village residents and
businesses, visitors to the community, and the general public, concerning the
Village, and the functions, activities, programs and issues of the Village. The
Village website constitutes governmental speech and is not intended to be used
for the purposes of advertising and/or as a public forum by an individual,
business, or group, nor as a mechanism for building exclusive support for a
particular person, program or issue. Therefore, links to candidate forums, even
if such forum, or the link thereto, has been organized and/or is sponsored by
what may appear to be a non-partisan organization shall not be permitted on the
Village website. Use of the Village website shall be authorized by the web
coordinator and governed by the operating procedures as set forth herein. The
Village website shall not be used by any person or group that seeks to foster,
promote, or encourage disharmony based on race, ethnicity, or national origin
or to otherwise seek to exploit differences among residents of the Village or
among people in general.
   E.   The Village web coordinator reserves the right to review all website
links, to determine its compliance with the Village website regulations and
purpose, objectives, priorities, restrictions, and access in accordance with
the provisions of this policy. Any website link under consideration may be
accepted as presented, may be rejected, or may be given conditional approval by
the web coordinator. Conditional approval of a website link shall mean that
such website link may be posted on the Village website on the condition that
any and all inappropriate, objectionable or offensive portions of said website
link, based upon local community standards, are removed before posting. The
presenter of the proposed website link will then have the option of making all
specified changes or withdrawing the proposed website link from consideration.
(Ord. 2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-6: WEBSITE UTILIZATION CATEGORIES:
Except as otherwise set forth above, the Village website may also be used for
the following governmental speech purposes, which are listed in order of
priority:
   A.   Emergencies: Emergency use may consist of written, live, or pre-
recorded informational postings and/or other applicable website links displayed
at such time(s) as are appropriate to the particular emergency. The purpose of
such postings will be to inform residents of emergency situations, and to
notify and instruct website visitors in evacuation, detour and/or escape
procedures. In the case of an emergency, other regular website utilization may
be preempted or canceled. The Village web coordinator, or his or her designee,
shall approve in writing all content and scheduling of any emergency
utilization pursuant to Village emergency plans, ordinances and policies.
   B.   Live Streamed Or Pre-Recorded Meetings Of The Corporate Authorities Of
The Village: Links to live streamed gavel-to-gavel coverage or re-broadcasts of
meetings of the Corporate Authorities of the Village will be available as often
as such meetings are scheduled, except in instances where the Village Board
adjourns to closed session(s) which closed session(s) shall not be available
for viewing, and no action by the Village Board after closed session other than
to officially adjourn the meeting is contemplated, in which case the meeting is
aired through the roll call on the motion to adjourn to closed session without
editing or editorial comment. Excerpts of a public meeting may be used by the
Village as part of a featured program or website link.
   C.   Live Streamed Or Pre-Recorded Meetings Of Village Advisory Boards,
Commissions And Committees: Live streamed or re-broadcast coverage of meetings
of Village advisory boards, commissions, and committees will periodically be
made available through the Village website based on location and staff and
equipment availability or upon request of the Corporate Authorities. Unless
covering only a specific presentation at a meeting, meetings are aired gavel-
to-gavel without editing or editorial comment. Excerpts of a public meeting may
be used by the Village as part of a featured program or website link.
   D.   Village Of Lake Barrington Communication(s): The content of Village
communication(s) posted on the Village website may include, among other things,
informative communication(s) produced or purchased by the Village which are
directly related to Village business or Village sponsored programs, services
and events.
   E.   Lake Barrington Taxing Bodies And Quasi-Governmental Entities
Communications: The content of communication(s) by Lake Barrington taxing
bodies and quasi-governmental entities posted on the Village website may
include, among other things, informative communication(s) by the Village and/or
by governmental bodies that have the authority to levy Property Tax on property
within the corporate limits of the Village, and/or to provide service within
the territory of the Village, and quasi- governmental entities of which the
Village is a member. Such communications will be directly related to Village
business or a local taxing body or quasi-governmental sponsored programs and
services.
   F.   County, Regional, State And Federal Governmental Content: The content
of communication(s) by County, regional, State and the Federal government
posted on the Village website may include, among other things, informative
communication(s) produced or purchased by said governments. Such communications
will be directly related to Village issues or governmentally sponsored programs
and services.
   G.   Community Programs And Events: Such content should be limited to
communication(s) and material sponsored by qualifying community organizations.
The content shall serve to strengthen community identity and brand of Lake
Barrington as "an oasis of gracious countryside living where businesses may
grow and prosper" and must have community-wide appeal and participation. The
content must be consistent with Village website purpose, objectives, access,
and content regulations and is subject to approval by the web coordinator.
   H.   Village Employment Opportunities Announcements: As approved by and at
the sole discretion of the web coordinator, or his or her designee, the Village
may post on its website contact information related to open positions for
employment by the Village.
   I.   Qualifying Community Organizations: For the purpose of this chapter a
qualifying community organization shall be a not-for- profit or governmental
organization located within and/or serving territory, residents, and/or
businesses within the corporate limits of the Village or within the area
covered by the Barrington Area Council of Governments (BACOG) which seek to
strengthen and enhance certain aspects of the community in accordance with the
mission statement. Only that content submitted by a qualifying community
organization that is consistent with the Village website purpose, objectives,
access and content regulations set forth in this chapter and is approved in
advance by the web coordinator will be posted on the Village website. (Ord.
2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-7: WEBSITE CONTENT AND CONTENT RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   The Village website shall contain, among other things, Village contact
and other information such as the address of the Village Hall, the names of the
Village's elected and appointed officials, including the Village's Freedom of
Information Act ("FOIA") Officer, Village departments, and an organization
chart.
   B.   The posting on the Village website of any content which is
inappropriate, as determined by the Village web coordinator or his or her
designee applying local community standards, is and shall be prohibited.
Inappropriate content shall include, but not be limited to, that which directly
or indirectly endorses any person or organization not directly associated with
the Village, commentary or personal opinions, photographs, music, video or
graphics not having the written permission of the copyright holder or proof of
being royalty-free.
   C.   The Village also prohibits the following website content, based upon
prevailing local community standards as determined by the web coordinator, or
his or her designee, and any communication or website link containing any of
the following will not be permitted:
      1.   Promotions, endorsements, or advertisements for any private business
(except as provided for in subsection 1-18-5I of this chapter), commercial
service or product or any paid advertising materials in which commercial
appeals for funds are made. Acknowledgment of grants or donations for
programming purposes shall not be considered as advertising. Paid advertising
material includes, but is not limited to, advertising by or on behalf of a
candidate for public office and program material made available with or without
charge by persons, corporations, or institutions which have a commercial
interest in the subject matter. This provision shall not prevent the
identification of persons or institutions providing grants or contributions to
underwrite the cost of programs unrelated to the commercial interest of the
donor or to programs which have a public interest overriding the private
commercial interest.
      2.   Materials or content intended to be used as a political forum by an
individual or group or as a mechanism for building exclusive support for a
particular person, program or issue. This section shall also prohibit links to
candidate forums, even if such forum or the link thereto appears to have been
organized and/or is sponsored by what may appear to be a non-partisan
organization.
      3.   Lottery or raffle information.
      4.   Religious programming with the exception of holiday music.
      5.   Any material or language which constitutes libel, slander,
pornography, obscenity or violence, as determined by local community standards.
      6.   Trademarks or copyrighted material, unless written permission for
use has been obtained in advance and a copy of which is provided to the web
coordinator.
      7.   Programming which is prohibited by applicable Federal, State or
local laws.
   D.   In the case of content deemed to be consistent with the Village website
purpose, objectives, access, and content regulations but also containing some
content or language that some persons may consider offensive, based upon local
community standards, the following message may be posted prior to the website
access to such content:
"The following material has been deemed worthy of communication through a link
posted on the Village Website, but contains language or other content that may
be offensive to some viewers. Viewer discretion and parental guidance are
advised."
(Ord. 2017-O-16, 9-5-2017)
1-18-8: ACCESS POLICY:
   A.   Access to the Village website may range from submitting a public
service announcement, requesting coverage of and/or posting of information
relative to a specific event, to working side-by-side with the Village web
coordinator, or his or her designee, to produce contents for the website. In
each case, the following procedures must be followed before access will be
provided:
      1.   All requests for posting(s) on the Village website must be submitted
in writing to the web coordinator on a Village of Lake Barrington Request for
Website Content Form which form may be obtained from the Office of the Village
Clerk, and must include the name of the organization for which the request is
being made along with the name, address, phone number, and email address of the
contact person and the organization's website address and should be submitted
at least ten (10) working days prior to the requested start date.
      2.   Content should be concise, and should contain basic information
concerning what, when, where, how, and how much. If necessary, the Village web
coordinator, or his or her designee, will edit the content to meet space
requirements, to improve readability of the content, and to insure that the
content is grammatically correct.
      3.   All submissions received will be reviewed by the web coordinator, or
his or her designee, and then posted to, linked to or denied posting on the
Village website, only at the discretion of the web coordinator. The web
coordinator is responsible for determining the appropriateness of the proposed
content. The web coordinator will use the website purpose, objectives,
regulations, and further limitations outlined in this chapter or otherwise by
the Corporate Authorities in making this determination. The determinations of
the web coordinator may be appealed as provided herein.
      4.   If the web coordinator determines that the proposed content must be
denied and/or is unsuitable for posting on the Village website, the material in
question will be returned to the applicant along with a written statement from
the web coordinator stating the reason for the denial and advising the
applicant that he, she, or it may appeal the denial to the Village Board in
writing within ten (10) business days of the denial. When appropriate, the web
coordinator's written statement may also offer recommendation(s) for modifying
the material in order to qualify for posting on the Village website.
      5.   The Village web coordinator, and/or his or her designee, will
endeavor to give timely consideration to all submissions of proposed content,
subject to priority, budgetary and staff-time constraints. (Ord. 2017-O-16, 9-
5-2017)
CHAPTER 19
POLICY FOR DONATIONS BY THE VILLAGE
SECTION:
1-19-1: Purpose
1-19-2: Public Announcements
1-19-3: Village Administrator Authority
1-19-4: Village President Authority
1-19-5: Village Board Authority
1-19-6: Maximum Amount Of Annual Village Donations
1-19-1: PURPOSE:
The primary purpose of donations made by the Village of Lake Barrington is for
the benefit and welfare of residents of Lake Barrington. This policy: a)
establishes procedures for requesting donations, and b) limits donation amounts
and identifies the respective authorities for approval thereof. (Ord. 2017-O-
11, 5-2-2017)
1-19-2: PUBLIC ANNOUNCEMENTS:
The Village Administrator will from time to time publish announcements
communicating to Village residents that donation requests should be submitted
to the Village in the months of February and March of each year so as to allow
review and consideration by the Village Board of such request(s) and the
possible approval of and budgeting for any such requests. The Village
Administrator will collect the requests and submit them to the President and
Board of Trustees for the Village Board's consideration and possible approval.
(Ord. 2017-O-11, 5-2-2017)
1-19-3: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR AUTHORITY:
The Village Administrator may authorize donations in amounts less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) such as flowers for funerals, etc., up to a maximum
of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per fiscal year. (Ord. 2017-O-11, 5-2-2017)
1-19-4: VILLAGE PRESIDENT AUTHORITY:
The Village President is authorized to approve donation requests up to one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) without approval by the Board of Trustees up to a
maximum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) in any fiscal year.
Once that two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) amount is exceeded in
any fiscal year the Board of Trustees must approve any additional requests for
such fiscal year. (Ord. 2017-O-11, 5-2-2017)
1-19-5: VILLAGE BOARD AUTHORITY:
Approval by the Board of Trustees is required for all requests for a donation
by the Village above one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 2017-O-11, 5-2-
2017)
1-19-6: MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF ANNUAL VILLAGE DONATIONS:
The maximum amount of donations approved by the Village shall not exceed in the
aggregate twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) in any fiscal year. (Ord. 2017-
O-11, 5-2-2017)
CHAPTER 20
FLAG DISPLAY POLICY
SECTION:
1-20-1: Village Flag Display Policy
1-20-1: VILLAGE FLAG DISPLAY POLICY:
The following flags are the only flags authorized to be flown or otherwise
displayed on or over Village-owned, -leased, or otherwise -controlled buildings
and property:
   A.   The official flag of the United States of America;
   B.   The official flag of the State of Illinois;
   C.   The official flag of the Village of Lake Barrington; and
   D.   The official National League of Families POW/MIA flag. (Ord. 2022-O-07,
7-11-2022)
TITLE 2
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
HOME RULE SALES TAXES
SECTION:
2-1-1: Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
2-1-2: Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax
2-1-3: Municipal Automobile Renting Occupation Tax
2-1-4: Municipal Automobile Renting Use Tax
2-1-1: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Pursuant to the authority provided to the Village as set forth in 65
ILCS 5/8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, a Home Rule Municipal Retailers'
Occupation Tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal
property titled or registered with an agency of the State of Illinois, at
retail in the Village of Lake Barrington (the "Village") at the rate of one-
half of one percent (½ %) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the
course of such business in accordance with the provisions of the Home Rule
Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act authorized by Illinois Compiled States.
Such Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax shall not be applicable on
the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the
premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food
which has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and
nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing
materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics.
   B.   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power
and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of this Section. (Ord.
2019-O-10, 11-12-2019)
2-1-2: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Pursuant to the authority provided to the Village as set forth in 65
ILCS 5/8-11-5, a Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation tax is hereby imposed
upon all persons engaged in the Village of Lake Barrington in the business of
making sales of service at the rate of one-half of one percent (½%) of the
selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman
either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate
as an incident to a sale of service. Such "Home Rule Municipal Service
Occupation Tax" shall not be applicable on the sales of food for human
consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other
than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared for
immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs,
medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles
used by diabetics.
   B.   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois
Department of Revenue. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power
and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of this Section. (Ord.
2019-O-10, 11-12-2019; amd. Ord. 2020-O-06, 3-3-2020)
2-1-3: MUNICIPAL AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of renting automobiles in this Village at the rate of one percent (1%)
of the gross receipts from such rentals made in the course of such business
while this Section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section
8-11-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 .
   B.   Reports Required: Every such person engaged in such business in the
Village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report
to the State Department of Revenue required by sections two and three of "An
Act in Relation to a Tax Upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling
Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption", approved June
29, 1933, as amended 2 .
   C.   Payment Of Tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid
to the State Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account
of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. (Ord. 82-O-05, 5-3-
1982)
 
Notes
1 3. S.H.A. 65 ILCS.
2 4. S.H.A. 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2-1-4: MUNICIPAL AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX:
   A.   Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in
this Village an automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and
which is titled or registered with an agency of this State's government in this
Village at the rate of one percent (1%) of the rental price of such automobile
while this Section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section
8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 .
   B.   Collection Of Tax: The tax provided for in this Section shall be
collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration
purposes is given as being in this Village.
   C.   Payment Of Tax: The tax imposed by this Section shall be paid to the
Illinois Department of Revenue. (Ord. 82-O-06, 5-3-1982)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 2
LICENSE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
2-2-1: Authority
2-2-2: Purpose
2-2-3: License Required Annually For All Businesses And Occupations, Other Than
Home Occupations; Disclosure Of Tenants
2-2-4: Business Records
2-2-5: Forms, Applications
2-2-6: Fees
2-2-7: Investigations
2-2-8: Buildings And Premises
2-2-9: Signatures
2-2-10: Posting License
2-2-11: Fiscal Year; Term
2-2-12: Changes In Location
2-2-13: Nuisances
2-2-14: Inspections
2-2-15: Suspension; Revocation
2-2-16: Recovery Of Fees
2-2-1: AUTHORITY:
This chapter and the provisions hereof are hereby adopted pursuant to the
authority of the Village as a home rule unit. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994)
2-2-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted in order to protect the health, safety and welfare of
the Village and to establish standards for the control and regulation of all
businesses or occupations, other than home occupations, and related activities
in the Village. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-3: LICENSE REQUIRED ANNUALLY FOR ALL BUSINESSES AND OCCUPATIONS, OTHER THAN
HOME OCCUPATIONS; DISCLOSURE OF TENANTS:
   A.   License Required Annually: Any person maintaining, operating, or
conducting any business, occupation or establishment, or doing business or
engaging in any activity or occupation or related activity generating any
revenue in any license year at any location within the B (Business), O (Office
and Research), and/or M (Manufacturing and Industrial) Zoning Districts within
the Village shall be subject to the licensing requirement of this chapter if by
himself, herself or itself, or through an agent, employee or partner, he, she
or it holds himself, herself or itself forth as being engaged in a business or
occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs
or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the Village
and all such persons shall obtain from the Village the required business
license as herein provided for, and pay to the Village the required annual non-
refundable business license fee, provided however, no business license shall be
required for: 1) a "church" as defined in section
8-2-2, "Definitions", of title 8 of this Village Code or a not-for-profit
corporation which has tax-exempt status, or 2) a lawful "home occupation" as
defined in section
8-2-2, "Definitions", of title 8 of this Village Code which is conducted in
compliance with this chapter and with section
8-3-5 of this Code.
   B.   Disclosure Of Tenants: Notwithstanding anything contained in this
chapter to the contrary, the license required for all businesses and/or
occupations, other than home occupations, pursuant to subsection A of this
section shall not be applicable to the activity of leasing as a lessor of
premises for use by others, when such premises are properly zoned for such use,
pursuant to the applicable provisions of title 8 of this Village Code, but each
person, partnership, corporation, association or land trust or beneficiary of a
land trust which has, as a lessor, leased any premises within the Village for
any purpose other than residential or agricultural uses shall annually and not
later than June 1 of each year submit a sworn list of all tenants who were
using or occupying such leased premises for any purposes other than residential
or agricultural uses, on the preceding May 1 or during any time during the
twelve (12) calendar months preceding said May 1 date. The beneficiaries of any
land trust which fail to comply with the requirements of this subsection shall
also be culpable for such violations and jointly and severally liable for any
fines or other penalties imposed pursuant to this chapter. Such disclosure of
tenants shall be on a form obtained from the Village Clerk and shall include
the name, address, telephone number and an accurate description of the business
or activity of each tenant. (Ord. 2006-O-24, 7-10-2006; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15,
12-6-2022)
2-2-4: BUSINESS RECORDS:
The Village Clerk shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all
business licenses issued by the Village for all businesses and/or occupations
conducted within the Village, other than home occupations, and shall furnish
the Village Treasurer with copies of each such license on not less than an
annual basis. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-5: FORMS, APPLICATIONS:
   A.   Forms: Application forms for all business licenses shall be prepared
and kept on file by the Village Clerk.
   B.   Applications:
      1.   Not later than May 1 of each fiscal year, applications for all
business licenses as required by this chapter shall be submitted in writing to
the Village Clerk on the respective form provided by the Village Clerk for that
purpose.
      2.   Each application for a business license shall state, at a minimum,
the name of the applicant, the email address of the primary contact for the
business, the federal and state tax identification numbers for the subject
business, as the use may be, the nature of the business or occupation, the
address and permanent index number of the location within the Village where
such business or occupation is or will be conducted, the time covered by the
requested license and the fee to be paid.
      3.   Each applicant for a business license may also be required to
provide to the Village such additional information as may be needed for the
proper guidance of the Village officials in issuing the requested business
license for the respective business or occupation which is being or will be
operated consistent with the applicable provisions of title 8 of this Village
Code. (Ord. 2001-O-18, 6-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-6: FEES:
In the absence of any provision of this Village Code to the contrary, all fees
and charges for licenses required pursuant to this chapter shall be paid at the
time application therefor is submitted to the Village Clerk. When an applicant
has not engaged in the business until after the expiration of part of the
current license year, the fee for same shall be prorated by quarters and the
fee paid for each quarter or fraction thereof except as otherwise provided by
this chapter during which the business or occupation has been or will be
conducted. Except as otherwise provided in this Village Code, all license fees
shall be deposited in the General Corporate Fund of the Village. The annual
business license fee shall be as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this Village Code for each fiscal year; provided, however, that in
the event an applicant for a business license fails to obtain a business
license or fails to pay the required license fee for same before May 1 of each
license year, or on or before sixty (60) days after establishing a new business
or occupation within the Village, other than a home occupation, requiring a
license within the Village, based upon the submission of reasonable evidence
thereof to the Village Clerk, the applicant shall pay, in addition to said
license fee, a late charge equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the license
fee, as established by section
1-10-7 of this Village Code, at the time of obtaining said license, which late
charge is necessary to cover the additional administrative costs of such late
application. No license shall be issued or renewed under this Chapter unless
the applicant is able to establish by written evidence acceptable to the
Village Clerk that all past due license fees and penalties due and owing to the
Village applicable to the applicant have been paid. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008;
amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-7: INVESTIGATIONS:
Upon the receipt of an application for a business license hereunder, the
Village may cause an inspection of the premises where such business or
occupation is or will be operated or investigation of the applicant for such
business license before the issuance of such business license. The Village
Clerk shall initially refer such application to such officer, agent or employee
of the Village as designated by the Village President for making such
investigation and/or inspection within ten (10) days of receipt of such
application by the Village Clerk. The officer, agent or employee designated to
make the investigation and/or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable
or otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving the application or a copy
thereof and provide such report to both the Village Clerk and the Village
Administrator. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-8: BUILDINGS AND PREMISES:
   A.   No business license shall be issued or renewed hereunder for the
conduct of any business, occupation, establishment, or related activity within
any B (Business), O (Office and Research), or M (Manufacturing and Industrial)
Zoning District of the Village, and no other license or any other permit shall
be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and/or building to be used for
the purpose in which such business or occupation is or will be conducted does
not fully comply with the requirements of this Chapter and all other applicable
provisions of this Village Code. No business license shall be issued except for
the premises specified in the application for such business license, and any
such business license shall be issued only for and shall be applicable only to
the premises specified in the respective application form, and no other(s).
   B.   An existing business licensee desiring to relocate the subject
business, occupation, establishment, or related activity to a new location in
the Village shall provide to the Village Clerk thirty (30) days prior written
notice of any such relocation and shall reapply for an amended business license
for the proposed new location, and the original business license shall be null
and void.
   C.   No home occupation shall be permitted by the Village which is or would
be in violation of any provisions of title 8 of this Village Code or be in
violation of any other applicable provision of this Village Code. (Ord. 2001-O-
18, 6-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-9: SIGNATURES:
All business licenses issued, except those license(s) evidenced by a sticker or
decal, shall bear the signatures of the Village President, or his or her
designee, and the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2001-O-18, 6-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2022-O-
15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-10: POSTING LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of any person or entity establishing, conducting,
maintaining, and/or operating any licensed business, establishment, or
occupation (other than a home occupation) in the Village to keep his, her, or
its business license posted at all times in a prominent place on the premises
where such business, establishment, or occupation is located and operated (the
"Licensed Premises"). (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. 1996 Code; Ord. 2022-O-15,
12-6-2022)
2-2-11: FISCAL YEAR; TERM:
The license year for any business license issued by the Village shall begin on
May 1 and end on the following April 30, unless otherwise specifically provided
by the business license as approved by the Village. The Village Clerk shall e-
mail all holders of a business license, at the email address of the primary
contact for the business as provided on the application received by the
Village, a notice to renew the respective business license reflecting the date
of the expiration of the current business license held by the licensee
approximately three (3) weeks prior to the date of such expiration; provided,
however, that a failure to send out such notice, or the failure of a business
licensee to receive such notice shall not excuse the licensee from obtaining a
new business license, or a renewal thereof in a timely manner, nor shall any
failure to receive such notice be a defense in an action for operating a
business within the Village without a license. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd.
Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-12: CHANGES IN LOCATION:
The location of any business or occupation licensed or required to be licensed
pursuant to this chapter may only be changed if the proposed new location is in
compliance with all applicable provisions of this Village Code and further
provided that thirty (30) days' prior written notice of any such relocation is
given to the Village Clerk. The holder of an existing business license shall be
required to apply for and obtain a new business license reflecting the new
address of said business pursuant to this chapter and provided that the new
proposed location shall be in compliance with all applicable provisions of this
Village Code prior to the commencement of any activity and/or operation of any
business at the new proposed location. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. Ord. 2022-
O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-13: NUISANCES:
No business establishment or occupation shall be so conducted or operated as to
be determined by the Village Administrator, or her designee, to be a public
nuisance. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-3-1994; amd. Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-14: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   General Inspections: Inspections by an authorized representative of the
Village shall be conducted of the premises to be used for or in connection with
the operation of a licensed business or occupation, other than a home
occupation, prior to the issuance of such license pursuant to this chapter
which inspection(s) are reasonably necessary to evidence or secure compliance
with all applicable provisions of this chapter and of this Village Code and to
identify any violations thereof, and it shall be the duty of the business
licensee, or the duty of the owner of the premises and/or the person in charge
of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the
inspection, any officer, employee or agent of the Village who is authorized or
directed by the Village to perform such inspection(s) at any reasonable time
that admission is requested.
   B.   Analysis: Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material used by, or
used in conjunction with, or offered for sale by a business licensee is
determined by the Village to be reasonably necessary to secure conformance with
any Village ordinance provision or to identify any violations thereof, it shall
be the duty of the holder of such business license to give sufficient samples
of each such material or commodity to any authorized officer, employee, or
agent of the Village requesting same for analysis thereof.
   C.   Failure To Comply: In addition to any other penalty which may be
provided for in this Village Code, the Village President may revoke or decline
to renew, or may suspend, the license of any business or occupation in the
Village, licensed to operate pursuant to this chapter or pursuant to this
Village Code, who or which refuses to permit any such authorized representative
of the Village to perform such inspection or obtain samples of material(s) and/
or commodity(ies) to complete the inspection, or take an adequate sample of the
said material and/or commodity in order to perform or cause to be performed an
analysis thereon, or who or which interferes with such authorized
representative of the Village while in the performance of his or her duty in
making such inspection; provided, however, that no business license shall be
suspended or revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the
business licensee or the person in charge of the premises, in the name of the
Village, stating that such inspection or sample is requested. (Ord. 94-O-08, 5-
3-1994; amd. 1996 Code; Ord. 2018-O-17, 8-7-2018; Ord. 2022-O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-15: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION:
   A.   Violation: Any business license may be suspended or revoked by the
Village President at any time during the term of such business license for any
violation by the business licensee of the provisions of this chapter or any
applicable Village ordinance relating to the business license, relating to the
subject matter of the business license or relating to the premises upon which
said business is operated and such suspension or revocation may be in addition
to any fine imposed.
   B.   Notice; Hearing; Cause For Suspension: Any business license issued
pursuant to this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the Village President,
after notice to the licensee and prior opportunity to be heard, during the
period of such license for the violation by the licensee of any provision of
this Village Code or of state statutes or regulations relating to the
respective license, the subject of the license, or the premises upon which such
business or occupation is conducted; such suspension or revocation may be in
addition to any fine imposed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Village
President is also hereby authorized to summarily order the cessation of any
business located within the Village, the closing of the premises upon which any
business is conducted, and the suspension of any business license for a period
not to exceed fifteen (15) days without any notice or prior opportunity to be
heard, where such cessation is immediately required to protect the public
health, safety and/or welfare of the community.
      1.   Hearing: Within ten (10) days after a written notice has been sent
to the holder of any business license, or after the Village President has so
acted summarily to protect the public health and safety, the Village President,
or his or her designee, shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining
whether or not the respective business license should be suspended or revoked.
      2.   Notice Of Hearing: Notice of hearing for suspension or revocation of
a business license shall be given in writing setting forth specifically the
grounds of the complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall
be sent to the respective business licensee at his or her last known address at
least five (5) days prior to the date for the hearing.
      3.   Hearing Procedures: At the hearing, the holder of the business
license shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence
and cross examine witnesses. The Village President, or the Village
Administrator, or his or her designee, shall preside and shall render the
decision and recommendation.
      4.   Causes For Suspension Or Revocation: Business licenses issued under
the ordinances of the Village, unless otherwise provided, may be suspended or
revoked by the Village President, or his or her designee, after notice and an
opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section for any of the following
causes:
         a.   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for the business license.
         b.   Any violation by the licensee of the ordinances of the Village or
State law relating to the subject business or occupation or the business
license thereof, the subject matter of the business or occupation or the
business license thereof, or the premises upon which the business or occupation
is conducted.
         c.   Conviction of the business licensee of any felony or of a
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
         d.   Failure of the business licensee to pay any fine or penalty owing
to the Village.
         e.   Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling or any interference
with a duly authorized representative of the Village while performing any such
inspections as provided in this Village Code.
   C.   Appeal Procedure: Any applicant aggrieved by the refusal of the Village
President, or his or her designee, to issue a business license or by the
suspension or revocation of a business license, shall have the right to appeal
the decision of the Village President, or his or her designee, to the Board of
Trustees. Such appeal shall be requested by submitting a written request to the
Village Clerk within five (5) days of the action of the Village President which
is appealed, which request shall state the reasons for such appeal.
The Board of Trustees shall consider the appeal at its next regularly scheduled
meeting which is at least four (4) days after the filing of such an appeal, at
which time the applicant shall be entitled to present his or her appeal orally
or in writing. The Board of Trustees shall act on the appeal at the hearing or
within a reasonable time thereafter and shall either uphold the action of the
Village President, or his or her designee, or shall direct the issuance of a
business license which the Village President, or his or her designee, had
denied or the reissuance of the subject business license which the Village
President has suspended or revoked. (Ord. 2018-O-17, 8-7-2018; amd. Ord. 2022-
O-15, 12-6-2022)
2-2-16: RECOVERY OF FEES:
Whenever any business license hereunder has been revoked or suspended pursuant
to this chapter, the business licensee shall not be refunded any monies that
have been paid for said business license. All fees for applications for any
business license are nonrefundable. (Ord. 2018-O-17, 8-7-2018; amd. Ord. 2022-
O-15, 12-6-2022)
CHAPTER 3
LIQUOR CONTROL AND TOBACCO REGULATIONS
SECTION:
