   A.   Definitions: In this section, unless the context or subject matter
otherwise requires:
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any table game, machine, apparatus, contrivance, appliance,
or device which may be operated or played involving in its use either skill or
chance, including, but not limited to, any pool table, billiard table, bumper
pool, tape machine, card machine, bowling game machine, shuffleboard machine,
marble game machine, horseracing machine, basketball machine, baseball game
machine, football game machine, foosball table, dart game, musical dancing
game, or any other similar mechanical or electronic game machine or device
(hereinafter referred to as "amusement device" or as "device").
ELECTRONIC AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any electronic device which, upon the insertion or
other use of a coin, token, prepaid card, slug, other mechanical or electrical
device, or the payment of a fee in some other manner, may be used by the public
for use as a game, entertainment, amusement, test of skill, either mental or
physical, whether or not registering a score. Without any limitation on the
foregoing, electronic amusement devices shall include, but not be limited to,
arcade type video games, pinball machines, musical dancing games and the like.
Electronic amusement devices shall not include billiard tables and other
similar table games.
PERSON: Any corporation, association, partnership, club, society or any
individual.
PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT OR OPEN TO THE PUBLIC: Any premises wherein any service,
food, or beverage or merchandise is offered for sale to the public or by the
general public or by members and guests of any club.
PROPRIETOR: The person in whose place of business any such amusement device is
placed for the use, amusement, patronage or recreation of the general public or
members and guests of any club.
TABLE GAMES: Games such as billiards, pool, foosball, table tennis, air hockey,
and the like that are primarily played on a table whether activated manually or
by the insertion of a coin, token, prepaid card, slug, or other mechanical or
electronic devices. Table games shall not include pinball, video games, and
other electronic amusement devices.
   B.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate within
the village an amusement device, either for gain or not, open to the public or
in any place of public resort, without a license therefor.
   C.   License Term, Sticker, And Fee: Any license issued for an amusement
device pursuant to this section shall be for the term of one year beginning May
1 of a specific year and ending on April 30 of the next consecutive year, and
the holder of any such license shall be required to renew such license no later
than April 30 of each year. Each amusement device proposed to be operated
within the village and licensed pursuant to this section shall bear a sticker
issued by the village clerk, which sticker shall be valid for a term of one
year beginning May 1 of a specific year and ending on April 30 of the next
consecutive year. The fee for each amusement device license and the related
sticker issued pursuant to this section shall be as specified from time to time
in section
1-10-7 of this code. In addition, renewal applications shall include a late fee
as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code.
The owner and/or lessee of such device(s) and the proprietor of the premises in
the village where such amusement device(s) is or are located shall be jointly
liable for securing the license for such device(s) and the payment of such
annual license fee for such device(s) as well as any applicable late fees. The
village clerk shall issue as evidence of payment of said fee a sticker which
shall be affixed to and conspicuously displayed on each such device.
   D.   Application For License: Application for a license for any amusement
device shall be obtained from and submitted to the village clerk, together with
a floor plan of the premises of operation pursuant to this section, by the
owner and/or lessee of such device or by the proprietor in whose place of
business any such amusement device is placed for the use, amusement, patronage,
or recreation of the general public or members and guests of a club and shall
be signed by the applicant, if an individual; by a partner in the case of a
partnership; or by an officer in the case of a corporation, club, association,
or society, verified by oath or affidavit; and shall contain the following
information:
      1.   The name, address, age, date and place of birth of the applicant, if
an individual; the names, addresses, ages, and dates and places of birth of all
general or limited partners, if a partnership; the names, addresses, ages,
dates and places of birth of all officers and directors of the corporation,
club, association or society, if a corporation, club, association or society.
      2.   A statement of the principal kind of business of the applicant.
      3.   A statement of whether corporate business will be conducted by a
manager, and the name, address, and authority of any such manager or agent.
      4.   The names, addresses, and dates of birth of all persons, firms and
organizations owning of record five percent (5%) or more of the corporation's
stock or five percent (5%) or more interest in a partnership.
      5.   A statement of whether any partner, officer, manager, director, or
shareholder owning five percent (5%) or more of the stock of a corporation has
ever been convicted of a felony or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a
felony charge, and a statement of any prior convictions of such persons for any
violations of the gaming laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or
of any federal gaming laws.
      6.   A statement of the personal history of the manager or agent to be
conducting business for the applicant.
      7.   The place where the device(s) is to be displayed or operated and the
business conducted at that place.
      8.   A description of each device to be covered by the license,
mechanical and electronic features, if any, and name of manufacturer of each
such device.
      9.   Whether said device is owned by applicant, and if not, the name and
address of the owner thereof.
   E.   Code Enforcement Inspection:
      1.   Prior to the issuance of any amusement device license hereunder, all
applications shall be submitted with a floor plan of the proposed premises to
the village administrator, or his designee, for approval of the proposed floor
plan, which shall show, include, but not be limited to, the following
specifications:
         a.   Square footage;
         b.   Exits (door locations);
         c.   Seating arrangement;
         d.   Amusement device locations;
         e.   Aisle widths;
         f.   Emergency and exit lighting;
         g.   Bathroom locations;
         h.   Schematic of electrical system, inclusive of floor plan; and
         i.   If electrical work is to be completed, an application or
electrical permit, together with a schematic of the electrical system,
inclusive of the floor plan.
The premises of operation for which application is made shall comply with all
applicable provisions of this code, including, but not limited to, the village
of Lake Barrington zoning regulations. Prior to any modification of the
proposed floor plan, any changes of or to the above listed floor plan
specifications shall be immediately submitted to the village administrator, or
his designee, for approval.
      2.   All applicants for amusement device license(s) shall:
         a.   Install and maintain on the premises where such devices shall be
operated approved crash bar device(s) for all exits.
         b.   Install on the premises where such devices shall be operated dry
type fire extinguisher(s), the number and location of which shall be determined
by the applicable fire district inspector, or his designee.
         c.   Apply for and obtain all other necessary permits and approvals
from the village as may be applicable.
   F.   Investigation: Prior to the commencement of the operation of any such
amusement device on a premises, the police department serving the village and
the building commissioner shall investigate the location wherein such amusement
devices are proposed to be operated and determine the accuracy of and verify
the information submitted by the applicant. The village is authorized to make
an inspection from time to time of the premises wherein such amusement devices
are operated to verify the number of licensed amusement devices and whether
each such amusement device bears the required sticker as issued by the village
and whether the premises conforms to the requirements of this section.
   G.   Eligibility For License: Amusement devices shall be allowed and
licensed only in compliance with the village of Lake Barrington zoning
regulations.
   H.   Village Clerk Issues Licenses; Waiting Period:
      1.   The application for one or more amusement device license(s) shall be
obtained from and completed applications submitted to the village clerk who
shall have the authority to approve or deny the license application based upon
the applicant's compliance with this section. Stickers for each amusement
device shall also be obtained from and issued by the village clerk.
      2.   No license shall be issued until at least thirty (30) days from the
date of filing of the application with the village clerk.
   I.   Display Of License: The license or licenses herein provided for shall
be posted prominently and conspicuously at the location of the amusement device
(s) in the premises the device(s) is to be operated or to be maintained to be
operated. It shall be unlawful for the owner or lessee of any amusement device
or of the premises within the village or any person in control of such premises
to permit the installation or use of any amusement device unless a license has
been issued for same and the fee has been paid and is evidenced by a sticker
affixed to the device. It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate said
sticker at any time during the year for which it was issued. Each such device
shall also be plainly labeled with the name, address, and telephone number of
its owner. No person shall keep or display for operation or patronage by the
public within the village any such device without first having obtained a
license and required sticker therefor from the village clerk.
   J.   Gambling: It shall be unlawful for any person owning, possessing, or
operating any amusement device to permit said device to include any form of
gambling or to include any scheme whatsoever to dispense any form of payoff,
prize, reward, except free games dispensed by the device, and nothing in this
section shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any
gambling device whatsoever or any mechanism which has been judicially
determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to the laws of the
state of Illinois. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
CHAPTER 2
ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Definitions
4-2-2: Registration Of Alarm System
4-2-3: False Alarms
4-2-4: Testing Of Equipment
4-2-5: Maintenance Of Equipment
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
ALARM HOLDER: The owner of an alarm system or the owner or occupant of the
premises within which an alarm system is installed or operated. In the event
that the owner of an alarm system, the owner of the premises and/or occupant of
the premises in which an alarm system is located are different, all of said
persons, entities, firms or corporations shall be jointly and severally liable
for any violation of this chapter.
ALARM SYSTEM: An assembly of equipment components or devices installed within
or on premises which is designed to signal the presence of any hazard or
emergency requiring urgent attention and to which police or the fire district
are expected to respond. Alarms systems shall include, but not be limited to,
fire, burglar and holdup alarms.
COUNTY: County of Lake, state of Illinois.
FALSE ALARM: The transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error or
mechanical malfunction, whether or not the exact cause of the error or
malfunction is identified or any other activation of the signal when no actual
emergency exists, except that the transmission of an alarm signal caused by a
weather related incident shall not constitute a false alarm. Any false alarm
shall be presumed to be not weather related and it shall be the burden of the
alarm holder to rebut the presumption that the alarm was not weather related.
FIRE DISTRICT: The fire protection district which serves the premises upon
which is situated the alarm system.
SERVICE CHARGE: An assessment by the village against an alarm holder for a
false alarm emanating from an alarm system as provided in this chapter.
SHERIFF: The sheriff of Lake County, Illinois.
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Barrington. (Ord. 88-O-02, 1-4-1988)
4-2-2: REGISTRATION OF ALARM SYSTEM:
   A.   Registration With Sheriff: No alarm system shall be permitted,
maintained or operated without first registering such alarm system with the
sheriff. The respective alarm holder or holders of each alarm system shall
register such alarm system with the sheriff prior to any operation thereof.
   B.   Liability For Alarm Service Failure: All registrants and all
manufacturers and companies under contract to maintain receiving alarm
equipment with facilities of the county, the fire district or the village shall
be deemed to have agreed that the county and the village shall not be held
liable for any alarm service failure and shall not be held liable for any
consequential damages resulting from such failure. Further, such registrants,
upon registering their alarm systems, also agree thereby that the village, the
fire district and the county shall not be held liable for any damage that may
result from the installation, maintenance or operation of the alarm system.
Such installation, maintenance and operation being the sole responsibility of
the alarm holder. Further, all alarm holders, by the act of obtaining issuance
of a registration to them, shall be deemed to have agreed to all of the
provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Indemnification: All applicants, by receiving a registration, agree to
indemnify, defend and save harmless the village, the fire district and the
county, their agents, servants and employees and the manufacturers and
companies, if any, under contract or agreement to maintain the receiving alarm
equipment in the village, the fire district and the county facilities, from all
claims, demands, judgments, liability, costs and expenses that may arise, in
any way, as a result or utilization of the alarm connection to the village, the
fire district and the county facilities.
   D.   Installation Costs: All registrants agree that the village, the fire
district, the county and equipment manufacturers and companies under contract
to maintain receiving alarm equipment within the county facilities, shall not
be liable for any costs or expenses of installation, maintenance of leased
services or any other charge or fees for any alarm equipment leased or owned by
the registrant.
   E.   Certification Of Alternate Power Source: All registrants at the time of
making application for a registration must certify that they have a system of
alarm maintenance available to them on a twenty four (24) hour basis and that
an alternative power source is available to prevent false alarms due to any
failure of power supplied by a utility company. (Ord. 88-O-02, 1-4-1988)
4-2-3: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   Service Charge: The first three (3) false alarms to the same alarm
holder in any calendar year shall be without charge. A service charge as
specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code, which shall be the base service charge, shall be billed to
the alarm holder for the fourth through sixth false alarms in any calendar year
and such service charge shall increase by an additional amount equal to one
hundred percent (100%) of the base service charge for each false alarm after
the sixth false alarm in any calendar year.
   B.   Payment Of Charges: Payment of such charges shall be made to the
village within fifteen (15) days after the notice of each such charge is sent
to the alarm owners. Should a test alarm be transmitted by a piece of
electronic equipment then under service by an alarm company, there shall be no
charge provided the alarm holder gives the village proof that the defect is
being corrected.
   C.   Failure To Pay; Filing Of Action: Failure or refusal of any alarm
holder to pay the service charge for false alarms may result in an action being
filed by the village against such alarm holder who is in violation of this
chapter. If such an action is deemed necessary by the village, the village
shall have the right to pursue all legal and equitable remedies against the
alarm holder.
   D.   Grace Period: A thirty (30) day grace period for new alarm systems or
for major modification or additions to existing alarm systems may be granted
upon application to and approval in advance by the village. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-
5-2008)
4-2-4: TESTING OF EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Prior Approval: Alarm systems transmitting emergency signals directly
to the communication center of the county shall be tested or demonstrated only
with prior approval from the sheriff.
   B.   Nonemergency Messages: Approval of the sheriff is not required to test
or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting emergency messages directly to
the communication center unless the messages are to be relayed to county
facilities. (Ord. 88-O-02, 1-4-1988)
4-2-5: MAINTENANCE OF EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Twenty Four Hour Maintenance: All alarm holders shall have a system of
alarm maintenance available to them on a twenty four (24) hour basis.
   B.   Alternate Power Source: All alarm holders shall have an alternative
power source available to prevent false alarms due to any failure of power
supplied by a utility company. (Ord. 88-O-02, 1-4-1988)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
4-3-1: Definitions
4-3-2: Cruelty To Animals
4-3-3: Animals Disturbing The Peace; Noisy Animals
4-3-4: Dangerous Animals At Large
4-3-5: Killing Dangerous Animals
4-3-6: Animals Running At Large; Leash Required
4-3-7: Diseased Animals
4-3-8: Cleanliness Of Premises
4-3-9: Animal Waste
4-3-10: Number Of Animals Limited
4-3-11:    Beekeeping And Apiaries
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
In construing the provisions of this chapter, except where otherwise stated or
clearly apparent from the context, words used herein shall be given their
common and ordinary meanings except the following definitions shall apply:
AT LARGE: Being off the property of the owner or keeper of the domestic animal
in question.
DOG: All members of the canine family.
DOMESTIC ANIMAL: This term shall include, but not be limited to, canine,
feline, bovine, equine, porcine, caprine, domestic fowl, and rabbits.
KENNEL: The keeping and/or maintenance of more than three (3) dogs, each of
which is more than one year old, or more than three (3) cats, each of which is
more than one year old. By way of an example in the application of this
definition, this definition and section
4-3-10 of this chapter would allow up to three (3) dogs, each more than one
year old, and/or up to three (3) cats, each more than one year old, for a
combined total of as many as six (6) animals which are each more than one year
old.
OWNER: Any person having a right of property in a dog or who keeps or harbors a
dog or has it in his care or acts as its custodian or who knowingly permits a
dog to remain on or about any premises occupied by him.
STRAY DOGS: Those dogs found in the public way or on private property other
than that of the owner. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999; amd. Ord. 2018-O-10, 6-6-2018)
4-3-2: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
No person shall cruelly treat any animal. Any person who inhumanely beats,
mistreats, underfeeds or abandons any animal shall be deemed guilty of a
violation of this section. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-3: ANIMALS DISTURBING THE PEACE; NOISY ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for a dog or other animal to disturb the peace by repeated
noise, and repeated noise for the purposes of this provision shall mean any
barking or other noise which occurs or reoccurs more than twice during any
twenty four (24) hour period. It shall also be unlawful for any animal to
disturb the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. The owner and
keeper of such a dog or other animal shall be jointly and severally liable for
any violation of this section. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-4: DANGEROUS ANIMALS AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous animal or any vicious animal of
any kind to run at large within the Village. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-5: KILLING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
The members of any police department serving the Village or any other
conservator of the peace is authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind
when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property. (Ord. 99-O-
05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-6: ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; LEASH REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to permit any "dog" or other "domestic animal" as defined
herein to run "at large", which is hereby defined as being off the property of
the owner or keeper of such domestic animal, unless such animal is secured on a
leash or physical restraint of strength sufficient to exercise control over
such animal. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-7: DISEASED ANIMALS:
No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be
allowed to run at large, or be exposed in any public place whereby the health
of man or beast may be affected. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-8: CLEANLINESS OF PREMISES:
No person shall cause or allow any stable or place where any animal is or may
be kept to become unclean or unwholesome. (Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999)
4-3-9: ANIMAL WASTE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for an owner, keeper or other person having
control of any animal to permit such animal to defecate or deposit excreta upon
any public property or upon any private premises not belonging to the owner,
keeper or other person having control of said animal without the consent of the
owner of such property.
   B.   The owner, keeper or other person having control of any animal which
defecates or deposits excreta upon any public property or upon any private
premises not belonging to the owner, keeper, or other person having control of
such animal shall immediately remove such excreta from any public property or
private premises as aforesaid.
   C.   This section shall not apply to a blind person while walking his or her
guide dog.
   D.   For the purposes of this section, the term "public property" shall
include, but not be limited to any public street, road, cul-de-sac, and/or
right-of-way, or any publicly-owned park, open space, preserve, and any other
publicly-owned land.
   E.   For the purposes of this section, the term "private premises not
belonging to the owner, keeper, or other person having control of such animal"
shall include, but not be limited to any property owned and/or managed by a
homeowners' association, condominium association, or common interest
association, unless such association has a published rule to the contrary.
(Ord. 99-O-05, 3-2-1999; amd. Ord. 2021-O-02, 1-5-2021)
4-3-10: NUMBER OF ANIMALS LIMITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to maintain a kennel on any lot or parcel within
the Village, except as specifically permitted by section
8-5-1 of this Code.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain on any lot or parcel within
the Village, for any length of time, more than three (3) dogs, each of which is
more than one year old, or more than three (3) cats, each of which is more than
one year old, except as specifically permitted by section
8-5-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2018-O-10, 6-6-2018)
4-3-11: BEEKEEPING AND APIARIES:
The keeping of honeybees, of the European species Apis mellifera, except for
Apis mellifera scutellata Lepeletier, shall be permitted as an accessory use in
any R-1, R-2, and R-5 Zoning District or in any Agricultural Overlay Zoning
District, subject to the following conditions and limitations:
   A.   Number Of Beehives: Two (2) full beehives ("hives") and two (2)
"nucleus hives" shall be permitted on residential lots and one additional
beehive and one additional nucleus hive shall be permitted for each additional
ten thousand (10,000) square feet of property over 40,000 square feet. For the
purposes of this Section, a "full hive" is any hive which exceeds five (5)
frame(s), and a "nucleus hive" is any hive which consists of five (5) frames or
less.
   B.   Location And Setbacks:
      1.   Setbacks To Property Lines: Hives and related structures that form
an apiary shall be located a minimum of thirty feet (30') from any adjoining
driveway, any improved easement for purposes of ingress or egress, or any
public or private road or street right-of-way and shall be no closer to side or
rear lot lines than ten percent (10%) of the average width of the lot,
provided, however, that in no event shall hives be located in any front yard.
In the case of an unimproved right-of-way, this provision may be modified by
the Building and Zoning Officer in consultation with the appropriate local
roadway authority.
      2.   Setback To Structures: Hives shall be located a minimum of thirty
feet (30') from dwellings, nonresidential buildings, patios, porches, gazebos,
decks, swimming pools, or permanently affixed play equipment, on an adjacent
property but may be within thirty feet (30') of storage structures such as
garages and sheds.
      3.   Signage: A sign, identifying the presence of beehives on the
property shall be posted so as to be reasonably visible within close proximity
of the apiary.
   C.   Management Practices:
      1.   Water Supply: A supply of water shall be continuously available and
located within the parcel. Water supply shall be designed to allow bees to
access water. Water requirement shall be in effect from April 1 through
November 20, or any and all days on which the temperature exceeds fifty five
degrees (55°) for three (3) consecutive days.
      2.   Requeening: In any instance in which a hive exhibits unusually
aggressive characteristics, as verified by an Illinois apiary inspector, the
property owner shall destroy, move to another parcel or requeen the hive within
fourteen (14) days of said verification.
      3.   Movable Combs: All honeybees shall be kept in hives with removable
combs, which shall be kept in good repair and usable condition.
   D.   Registration Fees: An initial non-refundable registration fee and
thereafter an annual registration fee shall be required for beekeeping and
apiaries as specified from time to time in Section
1-10-7  of this Village Code. (Ord. 2023-O-06, 3-2-2023)V
CHAPTER 4
GAMBLING
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Prohibited Acts
4-4-3: Exceptions
4-4-4: Keeping A Gambling Place
4-4-5: Penalties
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
GAMBLING DEVICE: Any clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machines or
device for the reception of money or other thing of value on chance or skill or
upon the action of which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded,
bet, won or lost; or any mechanism, furniture, fixture, equipment or other
device designed primarily for use in a gambling place. A gambling device does
not include:
   A.   A coin-in-the-slot operated mechanical device played for amusement
which rewards the player with the right to replay such mechanical device, which
device is so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation
thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and which returns to the
player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property.
   B.   Vending machines by which full and adequate return is made for the
money invested and in which there is no element of chance or hazard.
   C.   A crane game. For the purposes of this Section, a crane game is an
amusement device involving skill, if it rewards the player exclusively with
merchandise contained within the amusement device proper and limited to toys,
novelties and prizes other than currency, each having a wholesale value which
is not more than seven (7) times the cost charged to play the amusement device
once or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is less.
   D.   Gambling includes, but is not limited to, baccarat, twenty one, poker,
craps, slot machine, video game of chance, roulette wheel, klondike table,
punchboard, faro layout, keno layout, numbers ticket, push card, jar ticket or
pull tab.
GAMBLING PLACE: Any real estate, vehicle, boat or any other property whatsoever
used for the purposes of gambling.
LOTTERY: Any scheme or procedure whereby one or more prizes are distributed by
chance among persons who have paid or promised consideration for a chance to
win such prizes, whether such scheme or procedure is called a lottery, raffle,
gift, sale or some other name.
POLICY GAME: Any scheme or procedure whereby a person promises or guarantees by
any instrument, bill, certificate, writing, token or other device that any
particular number, character, ticket or certificate shall in the event of any
contingency in the nature of a lottery entitle the purchaser or holder to
receive money, property or evidence of debt. (Ord. 92-O-40, 1-6-1993)
4-4-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Gambling is hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the
Village. A person commits gambling when such person:
      1.   Plays a game of chance or skill for money or other thing of value,
unless excepted in Section 4-5-3; or
      2.   Makes a wager upon the result of any game, contest or any political
nomination, appointment or election; or
      3.   Operates, keeps, owns, uses, purchases, exhibits, rents, sells,
bargains for the sale or lease of, manufactures or distributes any gambling
device; or
      4.   Contracts to have or give himself, herself or another the option to
buy or sell, or contracts to buy or sell, at a future time, any grain or other
commodity whatsoever, or any stock or security of any company, where it is at
the time of making such contract intended by both parties thereto that the
contract to buy or sell, or the option, whenever exercised, or the contract
resulting therefrom, shall be settled, not by the receipt or delivery of such
property, but by the payment only of differences in prices thereof; however,
the issuance, purchase, sale, exercise, endorsement or guarantee, by or through
a person registered with the Secretary of State pursuant to section 8 of the
Illinois Securities Law of 1953, 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8, or by or
through a person exempt from such registration under said section 8, of a put,
call or other option to buy or sell securities which have been registered with
the Secretary of State or which are exempt from such registration under section
3 of the Illinois Securities Law of 1953, 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3,
is not gambling within the meaning of this subsection; or
      5.   Knowingly owns or possesses any hook, instrument or apparatus by
means of which bets or wagers have been, or are, recorded or registered or
knowingly possesses any money which he or she has received in the course of a
bet or wager; or
      6.   Sells pools upon the result of any game or contest of skill or
chance, political nomination, appointment or election; or
      7.   Sets up or promotes any lottery, or sells, offers to sell or
transfers any ticket or share for any lottery; or
      8.   Sets up or promotes any policy game or sells, offers to sell or
knowingly possesses or transfers any policy ticket, slip, record, document or
other similar device; or
      9.   Knowingly drafts, prints or publishes any lottery ticket or share,
or any policy ticket, slip, record, document or similar device, except for such
activity related to lotteries, bingo games and raffles authorized by and
conducted in accordance with the laws of Illinois or any other state or foreign
government; or
      10.   Knowingly advertises any lottery or policy game, except for such
activity related to lotteries, bingo games and raffles authorized by and
conducted in accordance with the laws of Illinois or any other state; or
      11.   Knowingly transmits information as to wagers, betting odds or
changes in betting odds by telephone, telegraph, radio, semaphore or similar
means; or knowingly installs or maintains equipment for the transmission or
receipt of such information; except that nothing in this subsection prohibits
transmission or receipt of such information for use in news reporting of
sporting events or contests.
   B.   Circumstantial Evidence: In prosecutions under this Section,
circumstantial evidence shall have the same validity and weight as in any
criminal prosecution.
   C.   Sentence: Gambling under this Section is a Class A misdemeanor. (Ord.
92-O-40, 1-6-1993; 1996 Code)
4-4-3: EXCEPTIONS:
Participants in any of the following activities shall not be convicted of
gambling therefor:
   A.   Agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance
including without limitation contracts of indemnity or guaranty and life or
health or accident insurance;
   B.   Offers of prizes, award or compensation to the actual contestants in
any bona fide contest for the determination of skill, speed, strength or
endurance or to the owners of animals or vehicles entered in such contest;
   C.   Pari-mutuel betting as authorized by the laws of this State;
   D.   Manufacture of gambling devices, including the acquisition of essential
parts therefor and the assembly thereof, for transportation in interstate or
foreign commerce to any place outside this state when such transportation is
not prohibited by any applicable federal law;
   E.   The game commonly known as bingo when conducted in accordance with the
bingo license and tax act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 25/1 et seq.;
   F.   Lotteries when conducted by the state of Illinois in accordance with
the Illinois lottery law, 20 Illinois Compiled Statutes 1605/1 et seq.;
   G.   Possession of an antique slot machine that is neither used nor intended
to be used in the operation or promotion of any unlawful gambling activity or
enterprise. For the purpose of this subsection, an antique slot machine is one
manufactured twenty five (25) years ago or earlier;
   H.   Raffles when conducted in accordance with the raffles act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 15/0.01 et seq.;
   I.   Charitable games when conducted in accordance with the charitable games
act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 30/1 et seq.; or
   J.   Pull-tabs and jar games when conducted under the Illinois pull-tabs and
jar games act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 20/1 et seq. (Ord. 92-O-40, 1-6-
1993)
4-4-4: KEEPING A GAMBLING PLACE:
Any person who knowingly permits any premises or property owned or occupied by
such person or under such person's control to be used as a gambling place
commits a violation of this chapter, which violation shall be a class A
misdemeanor.
   A.   Such premises are a public nuisance and may be proceeded against as
such; and
   B.   All licenses, permits or certificates issued by the village or any
subdivision or public agency thereof authorizing the serving of food or liquor
on such premises shall be void; and no license, permit or certificate so
canceled shall be reissued for such premises for a period of sixty (60) days
thereafter, nor shall any person convicted of keeping a gambling place under
this chapter or a similar statute be reissued such license for one year from
his conviction. After a second conviction of keeping a gambling place, any such
person shall not be reissued such license; and
   C.   Such premises of any person who knowingly permits thereon a violation
of any provision of this chapter shall be held liable for and may be sold to
pay any unsatisfied judgment that may be recovered and any unsatisfied fine
that may be levied under any section of this chapter. (Ord. 92-O-40, 1-6-1993;
amd. 1996 Code)
4-4-5: PENALTIES:
   A.   Class A Misdemeanor: Any person who shall violate a provision of this
chapter or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof, shall be
guilty of a class A misdemeanor, punishable by a term of imprisonment in other
than a penitentiary for less than one year and by fine(s) and other penalties
as specified from time to time in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   B.   Court Costs: Any person who shall be found guilty by a court of
competent jurisdiction of violating a provision of this chapter or of failing
to comply with any requirement thereof shall, in addition to the fine(s) and
other penalties provided, be obligated to reimburse the village for its
attorney fees to the extent permitted by law, court costs, court reporter
costs, expert witness fees and all other out of pocket costs incurred by the
village in the prosecution of the said violation or violations. (Ord. 2008-O-
05, 2-5-2008)
TITLE 5
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
VEHICLE STICKERS
SECTION:
5-1-1: Vehicle Stickers Authorized
5-1-2: Application For Stickers
5-1-3: Conditions Of Stickers
5-1-1: VEHICLE STICKERS AUTHORIZED:
The village clerk is hereby authorized to issue a motor vehicle sticker to each
resident and to each business or institution located within the village
applying therefor for attachment to any and all motor vehicles, title to which
is registered in the name of said resident or said business with the office of
the secretary of state of Illinois, department of motor vehicles. (Ord. 2003-O-
22, 12-23-2003)
5-1-2: APPLICATION FOR STICKERS:
The village clerk may require the following information on an application for a
motor vehicle sticker:
   A.   The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant.
   B.   That the applicant is one of the registered owners or leaseholders of
the said motor vehicle.
   C.   The year, model and make of the said motor vehicle.
   D.   The Illinois license registration (i.e., the license plate number) for
the current year. (Ord. 2003-O-22, 12-23-2003)
5-1-3: CONDITIONS OF STICKERS:
   A.   Contents: Said motor vehicle sticker shall state as follows and shall
be in the following form:
   LAKE BARRINGTON, ILL.
   (Year)
   Expires March 1, (of following year)
   VEHICLE TAG
   NO. V-1 (and successive numbers)
   B.   Fee Required: Said sticker shall be issued upon the payment of a fee as
specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code and presentation of a duly completed application pursuant
to section
5-1-2 of this chapter.
   C.   Display On Windshield: Display of such sticker shall not be mandatory,
but if displayed, said sticker shall be displayed on the windshield of the
motor vehicle for which it is issued in such fashion as not to interfere with
the vision of the operator of the vehicle.
   D.   Term: The sticker shall be valid for two (2) calendar years. (Ord.
2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
CHAPTER 2
TRAFFIC CODE
SECTION:
5-2-1: Adoption Of Illinois Motor Vehicle Code
5-2-2: Specific Adoption And Exclusions
5-2-3: Amendments, Modifications And/Or Additions
5-2-4: Illinois Route 59 Improvement
5-2-5: Specific Penalties
5-2-1: ADOPTION OF ILLINOIS MOTOR VEHICLE CODE:
There is hereby adopted by reference the following provisions of the Illinois
motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, as the same may be amended
from time to time, the same being a public record of the state, subject to
additions, amendments or modifications hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-
1-1992)
5-2-2: SPECIFIC ADOPTION AND EXCLUSIONS:
   A.   The following provisions of the Illinois motor vehicle code are hereby
expressly adopted by reference: chapters 1, 3, 4, 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 and 16
in their entirety, as they may be amended from time to time.
   B.   Excluded from adoption by reference and hereby deleted are chapters 2,
5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 17, 18 and the miscellaneous laws of the Illinois motor vehicle
code except as specified above. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
5-2-3: AMENDMENTS, MODIFICATIONS AND/OR ADDITIONS:
Chapters 3 through 7 of this title are amendments, modifications and/or
additions in the provisions in the Illinois motor vehicle code otherwise herein
adopted by reference. To the extent such amendments, modifications and/or
additions or any other provisions of this title are inconsistent with the
provision of the Illinois motor vehicle code herein adopted, the more
restrictive and specific regulation shall apply. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
5-2-4: ILLINOIS ROUTE 59 IMPROVEMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or permit or cause to be
discharged sanitary and industrial wastewater into any storm sewers constructed
as part of the improvement of Illinois Route 59 in the village. (Ord. 76-O-04,
6-1-1976)
5-2-5: SPECIFIC PENALTIES:
Every person convicted of violating any provision of the Illinois motor vehicle
code as incorporated herein by reference shall be punishable by one or more of
the following dispositions as are authorized for such offense by reference to
the Illinois motor vehicle code and as may be determined by the court:
   A.   Fine: Such maximum fine as authorized by reference to the Illinois
motor vehicle code;
   B.   Incarceration: A term of incarceration, either periodic or continuous,
in a penal institution other than the penitentiary for a period not to exceed
three hundred sixty four (364) days as authorized by reference to the Illinois
motor vehicle code; and/or
   C.   Supervision Or Conditional Discharge: A term of supervision or
conditional discharge as authorized by reference to the Illinois motor vehicle
code and the Illinois unified code of corrections. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
CHAPTER 3
PARKING 1
SECTION:
5-3-1: Stopping, Standing Or Parking
5-3-2: Obedience To Signs
5-3-3: Notice On Illegally Parked Vehicle (Rep. by Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
5-3-4: Presumption In Reference To Illegal Parking (Rep. by Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-
5-2013)
5-3-5: Relocation Of Vehicles In Emergencies
5-3-6: Regulations Relative To Specific Intersections
5-3-7: Police Officer
5-3-8: Parking Violations
5-3-9: Enforcement
5-3-10: Regulation Of Unscheduled Stops And Unloading Of Passengers By
Intercity Vehicles
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  5-5-2 of this title.
5-3-1: STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING:
   A.   Authority to Regulate and/or Prohibit: The President and Board of
Trustees hereby determine and designate those streets or parts of streets upon
which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles shall be and is hereby
prohibited at all times or within certain hours or permitted only for a limited
period of time or limited in the manner such as angle, parallel, or handicapped
parking only.
   B.   Parking Not to Obstruct Traffic: It is unlawful for any person to park,
stop or leave standing any vehicle upon any street, whether attended or
unattended, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available
less than fifteen feet (15') of the width of the roadway for free movement of
vehicular traffic except on a one-way street.
   C.   M, B or O Zoning District: No person shall stop, park or leave standing
any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon any street or portion of a
street in or adjacent to any M, B or O Zoning District, as designated on the
Official Zoning Map of this Village, for any purpose whatsoever, including, but
not limited to, loading or unloading, but this subsection shall not apply when
any official traffic control signal or sign requires a driver of a vehicle to
stop. Notwithstanding the foregoing, parking on Hillside Drive and Hillview
Drive shall be and is hereby permitted, except between the hours and at such
times that such parking is prohibited as provided in Subsection D below.
   D.   Night and Winter Parking; Restricted Hours: It shall be unlawful for
the driver of any vehicle to park said vehicle or for the owner of said vehicle
to permit said vehicle to be parked on any street in the Village between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day, or at
any time after snow begins to fall and for a period of twelve (12) hours after
snow stops falling, if the snow on the streets exceeds two inches (2") in
depth, provided that said parking restriction shall continue during snow
removal operations until completed, and except in any fire lane(s) as described
in Paragraph G below.
   E.   Parking Limited to Hard Surface: It shall be unlawful to park on any
private property located within the Village except within the confines of a
hard surface driveway (as defined in Section 6-4-5 of this Code) or within the
confines of a parking lot with such a hard surface.
      Notwithstanding the forgoing prohibitions:
      1.   Parking of vehicles shall be permitted on any gravel driveway
existing as of July 1, 2011, on any private property located within any
Residential Zoning District within the Village as designated on the Official
Zoning Map of the Village.
      2.   The temporary pParking of vehicles shall be permitted on other than
a hard surface driveway on any private property located within any Residential
Zoning District within the Village as designated on the Official Zoning Map of
the Village for a period or periods of time during any calendar month not to
exceed in the aggregate more than any portion of three (3) days.
   F.   Parking for Handicapped Persons:
      1.   It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not
bearing registration plates or decals issued to a person with disabilities, as
defined by Section 1-159.1 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, pursuant to
Sections 3-616, 11-1301.1 or 11-1301.2 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, or
to a disabled veteran pursuant to Section 3-609 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle
Code, as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with
disabilities or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private
or public off-street parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of
an official sign as designated under Section 11-301 of the Illinois Motor
Vehicle Code, for motor vehicles bearing such registration plates. Any motor
vehicle bearing a person with disabilities license plate or a person with
disabilities parking decal or device containing the international symbol of
access issued to persons with disabilities by any local authority, state,
district, territory or foreign country shall be recognized by State and local
authorities as a valid license plate or device and receive the same parking
privileges as residents of Illinois.
      2.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, any person found
guilty of violating the provisions of this subsection F shall be fined the
minimum fine as provided from time to time by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code
in addition to any costs or charges connected with the authorized removal or
storage of any motor vehicle under this subsection F. Each day a violation
occurs or continues shall be considered a separate offense.
   G.   Parking in Fire Lanes Prohibited: It shall be prohibited to park, stop
or allow to stand any motor vehicle at any time or for any length of time on
any private or public property in any area posted by signs as a "Fire Lane" or
designated as a "Fire Lane" by a yellow curb, or otherwise designated as a
"Fire Lane".
   H.   Truck and Trailer Parking in Residential Areas: It shall be unlawful
for the owner, operator or person having custody of or responsibility for any
truck or trailer to park such truck or trailer, or allow such truck or trailer
to be parked, on any street in the Village where the property adjacent to said
street, on either side thereof, is classified as part of any Residential Zoning
District as designated on the Official Zoning Map of the Village for a period
longer than two (2) hours unless such truck or trailer is actually engaged in
loading and unloading for a longer period. Nothing herein is intended to or
shall be construed as amending any ordinance providing for parking for a lesser
period of time or prohibiting parking. (Ord. 2011-O-18, 7-7-2011; amd. Ord.
2013-O-03, 2-5-2013; Ord. 2025-O-01, 1-14-2025)
5-3-2: OBEDIENCE TO SIGNS:
Where signs or curb markings have been erected upon any street as authorized
herein indicating that parking, standing or stopping is prohibited or is
prohibited during designated hours or prohibited for a longer time than is
designated, or limited to a specific manner of parking, it shall be unlawful
for any person to park, stand or stop any vehicle on said street in violation
of any such signs or curb markings. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
5-3-3: NOTICE ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
5-3-4: PRESUMPTION IN REFERENCE TO ILLEGAL PARKING:
(Rep. by Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
5-3-5: RELOCATION OF VEHICLES IN EMERGENCIES:
When any emergency arises necessitating the removal of any vehicle upon any
street, the village is hereby authorized to remove or have removed any such
vehicle from one location to any other location. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
5-3-6: REGULATIONS RELATIVE TO SPECIFIC INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Kelsey Road And Illinois Route 22 (Half Day Road):
      1.   Parking shall not be permitted and is hereby prohibited on Route 22,
seven hundred feet (700') west and seven hundred feet (700') east of the
centerline of Kelsey Road.
      2.   No person shall install, place, maintain or construct any structure
that encroaches upon the right of way for that portion of Route 22 located
seven hundred feet (700') west and seven hundred feet (700') east of the
centerline of Kelsey Road or upon the right of way for that portion of Kelsey
Road located six hundred feet (600') north and six hundred feet (600') south of
the centerline of Route 22.
      3.   No person shall discharge any sanitary waste or industrial
wastewater into any storm sewer or drainage facility constructed as part of the
Route 22/Kelsey Road intersection improvements located on Route 22, seven
hundred feet (700') west and seven hundred feet (700') east of the centerline
of Kelsey Road, and located on Kelsey Road six hundred feet (600') north and
six hundred feet (600') south of the centerline of Route 22.
   B.   Kelsey-Plum Tree Road And U.S. Route 14 (Northwest Highway):
      1.   Parking shall not be permitted and is hereby prohibited on Route 14,
on Kelsey Road, and on Plum Tree Road within the corporate limits of the
village of Lake Barrington.
      2.   No person shall install, place, maintain or construct any structure
that encroaches upon any portion of the respective rights of way for Route 14,
Kelsey Road, and/or Plum Tree Road within the corporate limits of the village
of Lake Barrington.
      3.   No person shall discharge any sanitary waste or industrial
wastewater directly or indirectly into any storm sewer or drainage facility
constructed as part of the Route 14/Kelsey-Plum Tree Road intersection
improvements located within any portion of the respective rights of way of
Route 14, Kelsey Road, and/or Plum Tree Road within the corporate limits of the
village of Lake Barrington.
      4.   No person shall be permitted to make any driveway entrance opening
into the curbs as constructed or to construct additional entrance(s), private
or commercial, along U.S. Route 14 within the corporate limits of the village
of Lake Barrington without the consent of the state of Illinois department of
transportation. (Ord. 2011-O-19, 9-6-2011)
5-3-7: POLICE OFFICER:
For purposes of this chapter, the following shall be applicable:
In addition to their usual meanings, the terms "police officer" and "law
enforcement officer" or any other similar term or terms as used throughout this
chapter shall also include and mean and refer to a village marshal and/or
deputy village marshal, if there are any, and any police or law enforcement
officers of another village or of Lake County serving the village by
intergovernmental agreement. (Ord. 92-O-30, 9-1-1992)
5-3-8: PARKING VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Notice On Illegally Parked Vehicle: Whenever any vehicle is parked in
violation of the provisions of this chapter and/or any ordinance prohibiting or
restricting parking and there is no person in attendance upon such parked
vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a traffic violation notice to
appear in court or administrative notice of violation to answer the charge of
such violation, any police officer observing such violation may attach to the
vehicle used in such violation a written administrative notice of violation so
that the person in whose name such vehicle is registered may appear in court or
before the village administrative hearing officer at a specified location on a
certain day and at a designated courtroom or other specified location to be
named in such notice and answer to the charge of such violation. It shall be
unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which said
notice is attached, to remove the same from said vehicle.
   B.   Prima Facie Proof: Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in
violation of any of the provisions of any ordinance or requirement of this code
prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is
registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to
the penalty therefor; provided, however, no person who is the lessor of a
vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be liable for the violation
of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking involving such vehicle
during the period of the lease unless such lessor fails to provide the name,
address, and driver's license number of the lessee within sixty (60) days of
receipt by such lessor of a request by the village for such information made
within one hundred twenty (120) days after the violation occurred. (Ord. 2013-
O-03, 2-5-2013)
5-3-9: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The police department serving the village shall issue a citation or
arrest ticket or administrative notice of violation in the case of each motor
vehicle parked in violation of the provisions of this chapter. Such citation or
arrest ticket or administrative notice of violation shall be placed upon the
motor vehicle and shall constitute service of a notice to appear in court or
before the village's administrative hearing officer, as the case may be, on the
owners and operator thereof. The penalty for any violation of the provisions of
this chapter unless otherwise specified shall be as specified from time to time
in section
1-10-7 of this code, provided, however, that penalties for particular
violations shall be assessed and may be settled, compromised and paid as set
forth in section
1-10-7 of this code.
   B.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
violation of this code, provided that the fine for such violation may be
settled by prepayment as provided in section
1-10-7 of this code.
(Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-5-2013)
5-3-10: REGULATION OF UNSCHEDULED STOPS AND UNLOADING OF PASSENGERS BY
INTERCITY VEHICLES:
   A.   Definitions: The terms used in this Section
5-3-10 shall be defined as follows:
   APPLICATION: A request for approval to stop and unload passengers in the
Village on a form to be provided by the Village Administrator, or his or her
designee, that meets all of the requirements of this Section
5-3-10.
   APPROVAL: A written notice signed by the Village Administrator after
consultation with the Lake County Sheriff, or their respective designee(s),
which approves an Application submitted in conformance with this Section
5-3-10.
   INTERCITY VEHICLE: Any bus, recreational vehicle, or other vehicle used for
transporting more than six (6) individuals and/or their respective personal
property between the Village and locations outside of the Village, but shall
not include or apply to:
   A.   Vehicles owned or leased by the Village or the Regional Transportation
Authority, including but not limited to the suburban bus commonly known as
"Pace";
   B.   School buses while providing transportation services to schools and/or
to other educational institutions;
   C.   Taxicabs, limousines, ridesharing vehicles, including Ubers and Lyfts,
or similar vehicles used for private hire by persons working or residing within
the Village or by persons visiting a specific residence or place of business
located within the Village when allowed or authorized by the owner of the
property;
   D.   Nor shall it apply to the disembarking of passengers arriving in the
Village for purposes of participating in Village-sponsored event(s);
   E.   A commercial undertaking for an existing Village business or
businesses, such as but not limited to, for example, the Lake Barrington Shore
Golf Club; or
   F.   A private event sponsored by an individual or individuals such as a
wedding or party for which transportation has been arranged in advance; any bus
or similar vehicle serving the respective residents of Lake Barrington Woods or
Lake Barrington Shores on a regular basis.
   LAKE COUNTY SHERIFF: The Lake County, Illinois, Sheriff, or his or her
designee.
   REGULARLY SCHEDULED SERVICE: A transportation service that operates trips
involving the dropping off of passengers in the Village on a predictable and
recurring basis, following a schedule that is published in advance and
available to the general public, and provides service in exchange for paying a
fare.
   UNSCHEDULED STOP: By Intercity Vehicle(s) means any location in the Village
where individuals are dropped off by an Intercity Vehicle that originated from
a location outside of the Village by a private or public transportation service
that is not providing regularly scheduled transportation service within the
Village and not operating pursuant to the written approval of the Village
Administrator, after consultation with the Lake County Sheriff, pursuant to
this Section
5-3-10.
   VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The Village Administrator of the Village of Lake
Barrington or his or her designee.
   B.   No Unscheduled Stops by Intercity Vehicles: It shall be a violation of
this Section for the owner, operator, or driver of any Intercity Vehicle to
make an Unscheduled Stop for the purpose of dropping off passengers in the
Village.
   C.   The parking, stopping, or standing of an Intercity Vehicle is
prohibited by this Section unless such vehicle has the prior written approval
of the Village Administrator in consultation with the Lake County Sheriff or
their respective designee(s) as required by this Section, and no exception to
this regulation shall be granted and/or provided unless expressly stated in
this Section.
   D.   Application Required: The owner, operator, or driver of any Intercity
Vehicle that is not providing Regularly Scheduled Service within the Village
that desires to make a stop to drop off passengers in the Village shall submit
an Application to the Village Administrator, or his or her designee, using a
form provided by the Village Administrator, or his or her designee. The
completed Application and all required information shall be submitted to the
Village Administrator for his or her approval, after consultation with the Lake
County Sheriff, at least five (5) calendar days prior to the date of the
proposed drop-off. The Application shall provide the following information,
including but not limited to:
      1.   The full name, full address, telephone numbers and email address(es)
of the Owner(s), Operator(s), and Driver(s) of the Intercity Vehicle. The
mobile phone number of the driver of the Intercity Vehicle shall also be
provided.
      2.   The full name, full address, mobile and land-line telephone numbers
and email address(es) of the entity or individual(s) that has or have either
directed, paid for, or financed the transport of the persons to be dropped off
in the Village by the Intercity Vehicle.
      3.   The full name of all persons that are proposed to be dropped off in
the Village along with copies of valid identification for each such person to
the extent that such identification exists or is or are in the possession of
each such passenger.
      4.   The name, address, or location in the Village at which the Intercity
Vehicle proposes to drop off passengers.
      5.   The date and time at which the passengers of the Intercity Vehicle
will be dropped off in the Village which shall only be allowed to occur between
the hours of eight o’clock (8:00) a.m. to five o’clock (5:00) p.m. on a Monday
through Friday, excluding any holidays.
      6.   The name and address of all locations from which the passengers of
any such Intercity Vehicle are being picked up for transport to the Village.
      7.   The full name, full address, mobile and land-line telephone numbers,
as well as all email addresses of all entities or individuals that shall be
present in the Village to meet the subject Intercity Vehicle and receive the
passengers when they are dropped off.
      8.   A detailed plan shall be submitted to the Village Administrator
together with each such Application identifying how and for what period of time
the individuals being dropped off will be cared for, housed, and fed, either
temporarily or permanently, upon being dropped off in the Village. The plan
shall include the full names, full addresses, and land-line and mobile
telephone numbers as well as all of the respective email address(es) of all
persons that will be present at the date and time of the drop-off and
responsible for the care, housing and feeding of the passengers. The plan shall
be executed by the person(s) and/or by an authorized representative of the
entity that agrees to be responsible for the care of the individuals proposed
to be dropped off within the Village and by at least one (1) additional
individual who shall be required to be present to receive any such passengers
and be responsible for their care. The entity and the individual that will be
present to receive the passengers and be responsible for their care shall each
by their signature certify that such person and/or entity will be responsible
for providing the actions detailed in the plan.
   E.   Approval of Application:
      1.   Within five (5) business days after receipt of a fully completed
Application pursuant to this Section 5-3-10, the Village Administrator, in
consultation with the Lake County Sheriff shall review same to verify its truth
and accuracy. If the Application is not complete, the Village Administrator
shall, in writing, advise the Applicant of any additional information and/or
terms needed to complete the Application. Failure of any person or entity to
provide all required information to the Village Administrator will cause any
such Application to be rejected by the Village.
      2.   The review of the Application by the Village Administrator in
consultation with the Lake County Sheriff shall take into consideration
administrative efficiency and available resources, public safety, and orderly
traffic flow, and an approval shall be subject to such conditions and
restrictions that the Village Administrator in consultation with the Lake
County Sheriff may impose in their respective sole discretion (including
without limitation, those addressing day/time availability of any such location
(s), number of daily arrivals/departures to and from any such location(s), and
advance notification requirements by the Applicant).
      3.   Within five (5) business days after receipt by the Village
Administrator of a fully-completed Application, the Village Administrator, in
consultation with the Lake County Sheriff, shall approve or deny such
Application in writing. If the Village Administrator, in consultation with the
Lake County Sheriff, denies an Application, it shall be based upon a
determination that the loading/unloading of passengers, luggage or other
personal property within the Village at that time, or at that particular
designated bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading/unloading zone or other
location presents an unreasonable threat to the health, safety, and welfare of
the public and/or impedes the safe and efficient flow of traffic and/or imposes
an unreasonable burden on available resources and/or based upon a determination
that any information in the Application is false, untrue, and/or inaccurate in
any manner. If the Village Administrator, in consultation with the Lake County
Sheriff, denies the Application, the Village Administrator shall send by email
or by regular U.S. mail a written notification to the Applicant specifying the
reason(s) for the decision. Any Applicant may seek review of the decision of
the Village Administrator denying such Application through the Administrative
Adjudication System of the Village by filing a request for review of such
decisions within twenty-one (21) days.
      4.   If the Village Administrator, in consultation with the Lake County
Sheriff, finds that the Application meets the requirements of Paragraph 3 above
and approves the Application, the Village Administrator shall inform the
Applicant in writing via email and by regular U.S. mail that the Application is
approved. The Village Administrator shall further provide a telephone number to
the Applicant or to the driver of the respective Intercity Vehicle to
coordinate the arrival of such Intercity Vehicle in the Village.
      5.   The Village Administrator, after consultation with the Lake County
Sheriff, may also require certified medical documentation that all passengers
are not presently, and have not within the last thirty (30) days prior to the
date of unloading, been diagnosed or has contracted any contagious disease such
as malaria, tuberculosis, or such other contagious disease that, if spread to
others, would adversely affect others' health, safety, or welfare; provided,
however, that such certification shall not be required of domiciled residents
of the United States who have not, within the last thirty (30) days prior to
unloading, traveled to a country experiencing an outbreak of any such
contagious disease.
   F.   Violations: It shall be a violation of this Section
5-3-10 for any individual or entity to violate any of the provisions of this
Section 5-3-10 and/or engage in the following action(s):
      1.   The submission of an Application that is false or untrue in any
manner.
      2.   The failure of any entity or individual that is responsible for the
care, housing, or feeding of any passengers dropped off in the Village to
promptly implement the detailed plan pursuant to the terms of an approved
Application.
      3.   Making an Unscheduled Stop by an Intercity Vehicle or Bus in the
Village.
      4.   Initiating any transportation of person(s) and/or property to the
Village without the required approval by the Village Administrator, in
consultation with the Lake County Sheriff, of the stop location without
submitting an Application and/or failing to obtain approval of an Application
as required by this Section 5-3-10.
   G.   Penalties: Any person or entity found liable pursuant to the Village's
Administrative Adjudication System and/or pursuant to the finding of any court
of competent jurisdiction, of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting, or
refusing to comply with, or resisting or opposing the enforcement of, any of
the provisions of this Section 5-3-10, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished by a mandatory fine of not less than Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00)
for each offense. A separate offense shall be regarded as committed each day
upon which said person or entity shall continue any such violation, or permit
any such violation to exist after notification thereof. The Village at its
discretion may enforce this Section
5-3-10 by:
      1.   A quasi-criminal action seeking the payment of a monetary penalty
adjudicated pursuant to the Administrative Adjudication System of the Village;
and/or
      2.   An action seeking monetary and injunctive relief filed in the
Circuit Court of Lake County or any other Court having jurisdiction over the
violator.
   H.   Seizure and Impoundment of Intercity Vehicle:
      1.   Whenever Village Administrator or the Lake County Sheriff, or their
respective designee(s), has reason to believe that a violation of this Section
5-3-10 has occurred, the Intercity Vehicle may be subject to seizure and
impoundment by the Lake County Sheriff in addition to any other monetary
penalty or other remedy that the Village may pursue. The Lake County Sheriff
may, in the exercise of his or her discretion, provide for the towing of such
Intercity Vehicle to a facility approved by the Lake County Sheriff.
      2.   Upon the towing of any such Intercity Vehicle pursuant to this
Section, the Lake County Sheriff shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to
notify the owner of record, lessee, person claiming to be the owner or lessee,
or any person who is found to be in control of the Intercity Vehicle at the
time of the alleged violation of the fact of the seizure and of the vehicle
owner's right to request an administrative hearing on such seizure.
   I.   Administrative Tow Hearing;
      1.   Within five (5) business days after an Intercity Vehicle is seized
and impounded as provided by this Section
5-3-10, the Village Administrator, or his or her designee, in consultation with
the Lake County Sheriff, shall notify, by personal service, first class mail,
or certified mail, the owner of record, lessee, and any lienholder of record of
the owner's right to request a hearing to determine whether a violation of this
Section 5-3-10 actually occurred. The name and address of the person to whom a
vehicle is registered as shown on the records of the State in which the vehicle
is registered shall be conclusive evidence of the name and address of the owner
of record of the vehicle, unless the owner of record gave the Village actual
written notice of a different name or address.
      2.   In order to obtain a hearing, the owner of record must file a
written request for a hearing with the Village Administrator, or his or her
designee, no later than ten (10) business days after the date the notice was
mailed. The hearing date must be scheduled for a date that is no more than
fifteen (15) business days after a request for a hearing has been filed. The
person requesting the hearing shall be given at least five (5) business days'
notice of the date of the hearing.
      3.   The hearing shall be conducted by the Administrative Adjudication
Hearing Officer (the "Hearing Officer") of the Village appointed in accordance
with Chapter 17, "Administrative Adjudication System", of Title 1,
"Administration", of this Village Code. The owner of the Intercity Vehicle
shall have the right to be represented by an attorney; the right to notice of
the charges causing the seizure and impoundment of the Intercity Vehicle; the
right to present witness and documentary evidence, and the right to cross-
examine all witnesses.
      4.   If, after the hearing, the Administrative Adjudication Hearing
Officer determines, by a preponderance of evidence, that a violation of this
Section 5-3-10 has occurred involving the seized and impounded Intercity
Vehicle or Bus, then the Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer shall
enter an order finding the owner of record of the vehicle liable to the Village
for the administrative fee of Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00), which
shall be in addition to any other penalties, mandatory fine(s) and remedy
sought by the Village.
      5.   If, after a hearing, the Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer
does not determine, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the vehicle was
used in violation of Section 5-3-10 of this Code, the Administrative
Adjudication Hearing Officer shall enter an order finding for the owner and
ordering the return of the vehicle.
      6.   If the owner of record fails to request a hearing on the seizure and
impoundment of an Intercity Vehicle in a timely manner or fails to appear at
the hearing, the owner of record shall be deemed to have waived the owner's
right to a hearing, and the Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer may
enter a default order in favor of the Village in the amount of the
administrative fee(s). However, if the owner of record pays such fee(s) and the
vehicle is returned to the owner, no default order need be entered if the owner
is informed of his or her right to a hearing and executes a written waiver of
such right to a hearing, in which case, an order of liability shall be deemed
to have been made when the Village receives the written waiver.
   J.   Requirements for Recovery of a Seized and Impounded Intercity Vehicle
or Bus: A vehicle impounded pursuant to this Section 5-3-10 shall remain
impounded until:
      1.   The administrative fee(s) of Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars
($750.00) are paid to the Village or the Lake County Sheriff and all applicable
towing fees are paid to the towing agent, in which case, the owner of record
shall be given possession of the Intercity Vehicle; or
      2.   A bond in the amount of Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) is
posted with the Village and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing
agent, at which time, the Intercity Vehicle will be released to the owner of
record; or
      3.   The Intercity Vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case, it shall
be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned
vehicles.
   K.   Posting Bond:
      1.   If a bond in the amount of Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) is
posted with the Lake County Sheriff's Department or with the Village Treasurer,
the impounded Intercity Vehicle shall be released to the owner of record,
provided, however, the owner of the Intercity Vehicle or Bus shall still be
liable to the towing agent for any applicable towing fees.
      2.   If, after an Administrative Hearing on the seizure and impoundment
of the Intercity Vehicle or Bus, it is determined that the Intercity Vehicle
was used in violation of Section
5-3-10, the posted bond shall be forfeited to the Village; however, if a
violation of Section
5-3-10 is not proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the bond will be
returned to the person posting the bond, and all towing fees shall be waived.
      3.   All bond money posted pursuant to this Chapter shall be held by the
Village until the Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer issues a decision
or, if there is a judicial review, until a final order is entered in the
judicial proceeding in which review is sought.
   L.   Disposition of an Unclaimed Intercity Vehicle: Any Intercity Vehicle
that is not reclaimed or subject to judicial review within thirty-five (35)
days after the Village's Administrative Hearing Officer issues a final written
decision shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle as
provided by law.
(Ord. 2024-O-02, 1-17-2024)
CHAPTER 4
SPEED LIMITS
SECTION:
5-4-1: Thirty Five Miles Per Hour
5-4-2: Thirty Miles Per Hour
5-4-3: Twenty Five Miles Per Hour
5-4-4: Twenty Miles Per Hour
5-4-5: State And County Jurisdiction
5-4-1: THIRTY FIVE MILES PER HOUR:
Based upon a traffic or engineering investigation, the reasonable and safe

specified, is hereby established at thirty five (35) miles per hour. It shall
be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle on any of the following roads, streets
or highways in the village at a speed in excess of thirty five (35) miles per
hour:
Anderson Road
(Ord. 2006-O-37, 11-13-2006)

within the area indicated below:

5-5-3: EMERGENCY ACCESS LOCATIONS:
   A.   Definition: For purposes of this section, a "vehicle" is defined as
every device in or upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved or used by human
power, and the term "vehicular" refers to all such "vehicles". The term
"vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, both motor vehicles and trailers.
   B.   Emergency Access Locations Closed To Regular Vehicular Traffic:
      1.   The following emergency access locations within the village which
have been authorized and/or approved by the village are hereby closed to all
vehicular traffic except as permitted by this section:
         a.   Between Flint Drive, a village right of way, in Flint Lake
Subdivision and Hawk's Nest Circle, a private right of way in the Enclave At
Heritage Estates Subdivision.
         b.   Between Savannah Court, a village right of way in the Savannah
Subdivision, and Highway 22, an Illinois highway, across the property of
Citizens For Conservation, Inc.
      2.   Only the following persons and vehicles shall be authorized to use
such emergency access locations:
         a.   Authorized emergency vehicles and emergency personnel at all
times.
         b.   Any person or persons specifically authorized to perform
maintenance on said emergency access easement(s) by the board of trustees, by
the village president, or his designee, by the village administrator, or by the
village engineer.
   C.   Penalties: Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or
refuses to comply with or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of
this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense,
and each day on which a violation occurs or continues to exist shall constitute
a separate offense. (Ord. 2005-O-33, 10-4-2005)
CHAPTER 6
WEIGHT LIMITS
SECTION:
5-6-1: General Provisions; Overweight Vehicles
5-6-2: Temporary Prohibition Of Certain Classes Of Vehicles
5-6-3: Exceptions
5-6-4: Enforcement And General Penalties
5-6-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS; OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES:
The maximum weight limitations set forth in this chapter are hereby imposed on
the designated roads, streets and highways under the jurisdiction of the
village, which maximum weight limitations shall be effective when appropriate
regulatory signs giving notice thereof are erected on such roads, streets and
highways. Except as specifically provided in section
5-6-3 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle (including,
but not limited to, any truck, tractor, trailer or combination of units, or
other commercial vehicle with or without accompanying load) with a gross weight
of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds or greater (maximum weight limitation) on
the following street(s) within the village:
Alice Lane.
Anderson Road. (Ord. 2008-O-27, 10-7-2008)
5-6-2: TEMPORARY PROHIBITION OF CERTAIN CLASSES OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Condition Of Roadway: Whenever any road, street or highway, or parts
thereof, under the jurisdiction of this village, by reason of deterioration,
rain, snow or other climatic conditions, may be seriously damaged or destroyed
by the use of trucks or other commercial vehicles, the operation of said
vehicles thereon shall be prohibited or the permissible weight thereof reduced.
   B.   Resolution To Prohibit: The chairperson of the village roads committee
or the village president are hereby authorized to determine and designate the
time and the roads, streets or highways, or parts thereof, which may be so
seriously damaged or destroyed as above provided, and shall so advise the board
of trustees of the village. The board of trustees, by resolution, may prohibit
the operation of trucks or other commercial vehicles over and upon such roads,
streets or highways, or parts thereof, so designated, provided that said
