      2.   The distribution to and into the subsystems is by low pressure pipe
in accordance with subsection 12-7-3B2 and Section
12-7-4 of this Title, as applicable.
      3.   The supply line is split by a single diverter valve into supply
lines to each of the subsystems.
      4.   An agreement is established with a licensed contractor to alternate
the use of the subfields on a yearly basis.
   B.   Special Use Systems: A special use system as provided for in this
Section may be approved by the Village Board by a variation to accept, in whole
or in part, the wastewater flow for treatment and disposal. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-
17-1996)
12-8-4: SPECIAL USE SYSTEMS:
   A.   Variance Approval: Whenever an individual sewage disposal system cannot
be approved because a soil absorption system cannot meet the requirements of
this Title, the Village Board may approve a variation for a special use
absorption system to accept, in whole or in part, wastewater for treatment and
disposal.
   B.   Surface Discharging System: Buried sand filters, recirculating sand
filters, Class I aerobic units, or other wastewater treatment processes
designed to treat, disinfect, and discharge to the surface may be approved by
the Village Board by a variation provided that:
      1.   Failing System: The system is proposed to replace a substandard
existing system for an existing structure.
      2.   Unsuitable Soil: All suitable soils on the site have been employed
for wastewater infiltration.
      3.   Dilution: A discharge point to a surface water or wetland provides a
minimum 1:1 dilution of the effluent.
      4.   Recreational Water Restriction: The proposed discharge point is a
minimum of one-fourth (1/4) mile from an area used for recreational purposes.
      5.   System Design: The proposed system is designed to meet final
discharge effluent standards as follows:
         a.   BOD5 less than 30 ppm.
         b.   Total suspended solids less than 30 ppm.
         c.   Fecal coliform less than 400 organism/100 ml.
         d.   Residual chlorine 1.0 ppm.
   C.   Experimental Systems: The Village Board may consider, upon request, the
approval of a variation for proposed wastewater system which is different in
process or design from the specifications of this Title. The consideration of
approval of a variation for any such experimental system shall include a review
of existing performance data, if any, and an evaluation of applicable technical
criteria relative to the treatment and/or disposal of wastewater as proposed in
comparison to the intent of this Title. Any system proposed for an experimental
use shall be approved, additionally, by the Illinois Department of Public
Health. Such approval may be by the IDPH experimental use permitting procedure,
or by special consideration by IDPH of the specific proposal and individual
circumstance.
      1.   Approved Systems: The following system designs are approved, having
received approval status through the Illinois Department of Public Health
Experimental Use protocol:
         a.   Aquarobic raised filter bed;
         b.   Infiltrator chamber, models EQ-36 and EQ-24. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-
17-1996)
12-8-5: ADMINISTRATION; PROCEDURE:
Administrative procedure and fees relative to this Chapter shall be in
accordance with Chapter 16 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 9
PLANS
SECTION:
12-9-1: Plans Required
12-9-2: Site Plan Specifications
12-9-3: Plan Specifications For System Components, Repairs, Replacements Or
Additions
12-9-4: Supplemental Information
12-9-5: Proposed Subdivisions
12-9-1: PLANS REQUIRED:
Prior to granting approval for an individual sewage disposal system, the
Enforcement Officer shall review a site plan prepared according to this Chapter
to determine the compliance of the proposed individual sewage disposal system
with the requirements of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-9-2: SITE PLAN SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Minimum Standards: Any plan for an individual sewage disposal system,
except where the proposal is only to repair, replace or add septic tanks, lift
stations, pretreatment units or other components other than soil absorption
capacity, shall meet minimum standards as established in this Section.
   B.   Professional Engineer: The plan shall be prepared by an Illinois
licensed professional engineer.
   C.   Topographical Survey: The plan shall be drawn on a topographical
survey, as defined by Section
12-2-2 of this Title, to provide accurate contour lines depicting each one foot
(1') change in elevation of the site and adjacent property within twenty five
feet (25') of the site.
   D.   Plan Size, Scale: The plan shall be drawn on a minimum size sheet of
eleven inches by seventeen inches (11" x 17") and to a scale of one inch equals
ten feet (1" = 10'), one inch equals twenty feet (1" = 20'), or one inch equals
thirty feet (1" = 30'), unless otherwise approved.
   E.   Readable Copies: The plan shall be prepared and copied so as to be
easily readable. Minimum text size shall be font eight (8).
   F.   Dimensions: The plan shall properly locate and specify dimensions for:
      1.   Property Lines: All property lines.
      2.   Improvements: The elevation and location of all existing and
proposed buildings, driveways and other improvements, including proposed ground
contour lines depicting each one foot (1') change in elevation.
      3.   Utilities: All utility easements, underground utility and service
lines, and any overhead utility lines within twenty five feet (25') of the
proposed well location.
      4.   Water Wells: All existing and proposed water wells on the property
or within seventy five feet (75') of a property line; the entire radius of any
proposed well shall be contained on the subject property, whenever possible.
      5.   Individual Sewage Disposal Systems: All existing and proposed
individual sewage disposal systems on the property or within seventy five feet
(75') of a property line.
      6.   Drainage: All drainage easements, ditches, streams, swales or other
storm water pathways, including storm sewers, culverts and field tiles within
twenty five feet (25') of the subject property.
      7.   Surface Waters/Wetlands: All surface waters or wetlands on the
property or within one hundred feet (100') of a property line. Based upon the
discretion of the Enforcement Officer, a wetland delineation may be required.
      8.   Existing Roads And Ditches: Point elevations of existing roadside
ditches, edge and center of existing road pavement and existing road and
driveway culvert pipe inverts within seventy five feet (75') of the subject
property.
      9.   Site Development: Specific alterations to a site related to the
construction of the proposed individual sewage disposal system.
   G.   ISD Specifications: The plan shall properly locate and provide
dimensions or specifications for the proposed individual sewage disposal system
as follows:
      1.   Individual Sewage Disposal Components: Location and size of all
septic tanks, pretreatment units and lift stations.
      2.   Soil Evaluation: Location of all soil evaluation points.
      3.   Components: Location and size of all components of the soil
absorption system as applicable, including:
         a.   Piping to the soil absorption system.
         b.   Distribution boxes, drop boxes, diverter valves.
         c.   Soil absorption trenches.
         d.   Pressure distribution piping in at-grade or mound system.
         e.   Gravel application beds in mound systems.
         f.   Areas of approved filling.
      4.   Storage/Traffic: Location for material storage and a pathway for
construction traffic.
   H.   Specific Elevations: The plan shall provide specific elevations,
referenced to the topographical survey as follows:
      1.   Benchmark: The elevation of a permanent benchmark within three
hundred feet (300') of the site and referenced to U.S. Geological Survey (mean
sea level) National Geodetic Vertical Datum.
      2.   Floodplain: The elevation of floodplain, if any.
      3.   Sewer/Septic: The elevations of the invert of the building sewer and
the inlet(s) of the septic tank or other pretreatment units.
      4.   Distribution Box: The elevation of the invert of a distribution box,
except where a lift station is proposed.
      5.   Distribution Line: The elevation of any low pressure lateral
distribution line.
   I.   Detailed Cross-Section: A detailed cross-section for the soil
absorption system specifying original grade and the relative placement of fill
material, gravel, piping and cover material.
   J.   Required Additional Information: The plan shall include additional
information as follows:
      1.   Legal Description: A legal description of the property.
      2.   Property Location: A sketch of the property location. (Ord. 96-O-16,
12-17-1996; amd. Ord. 2021-O-12, 9-7-2021)
12-9-3: PLAN SPECIFICATIONS FOR SYSTEM COMPONENTS, REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR
ADDITIONS:
   A.   Minimum Standards: A plan submitted for approval where the proposal is
only to repair, replace or add system components other than soil absorption
capacity shall meet minimum standards as established in this Section.
   B.   Contractor, Professional Engineer: The plan shall be prepared by a
person licensed as a private sewage system installation contractor or a
professional engineer in accordance with Chapter 12 of this Title.
   C.   Scale: The plan shall be to a scale of one inch equals ten feet (1" =
10'), one inch equals twenty feet (1" = 20'), or one inch equals thirty feet
(1" = 30') unless otherwise approved.
   D.   Readable Copies: The plan shall be prepared and copied so as to be
easily readable. Minimum text size shall be font eight (8).
   E.   Plan Requirements: The plan shall show:
      1.   Buildings: The location of any buildings.
      2.   Existing Components: The location of the existing components of the
system.
      3.   Proposed System: The location and size as applicable of the proposed
repair, replacement or addition.
      4.   Water: The location of water wells and/or water supply lines.
      5.   Separation Requirements: Other information as is applicable to the
requirements of this Title for separation requirements in accordance with
Appendix D of this Title.
      6.   Legal Description: A legal description of the property.
      7.   Site Development: Specific alterations to a site related to the
repair, replacement or addition of system components. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-
1996)
12-9-4: SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION:
   A.   Required Information: Any individual sewage disposal system plan
submitted for approval shall be submitted with permit application forms
provided and shall include any other information detailing the design of the
individual sewage disposal system, where applicable, as established by this
Section.
   B.   Soil Evaluation: The soil evaluation report.
   C.   Projected Wastewater Flow: A calculation of the projected wastewater
daily flow, including a floor plan of a proposed residence or establishment.
   D.   Component Capacity: A calculation of the capacity of the components of
the system and of the soil absorption system.
   E.   Length Calculation: A calculation of the bed length of an at- grade or
mound system as referenced in subsection 12-7-3B3 and 4 of this Title.
   F.   Low Pressure Pipe Distribution System Calculation: A calculation of low
pressure pipe distribution system as referenced in subsection 12-7-4A of this
Title.
   G.   Other Applicable Information: Reports from engineers, wetland
consultants, or other professionals, as may be required to establish storm
water drainage, wetland delineations, surface water elevations, floodplain or
other applicable information necessary for the evaluation of the plan.
   H.   Variance Request: Other information as may be applicable for
consideration of a variance request. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-9-5: PROPOSED SUBDIVISIONS:
   A.   Minimum Standards: Any preliminary plat or plan for a new subdivision
submitted for approval shall meet minimum requirements as established by this
Section.
   B.   Licensed Professional Engineer: The plan shall be prepared by an
Illinois licensed professional engineer.
   C.   Topographical Survey: The plan shall be drawn on a topographical survey
as defined by Section
12-2-2 of this Title to provide accurate contour lines depicting each one foot
(1') change in elevation.
   D.   Scale: The plan shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals one
hundred feet (1" = 100') or less.
   E.   Soil Evaluation Points And Soil Classifications: A drawing at the same
scale as the preliminary plat or plan shall be prepared by a certified soil
classifier. The following information shall appear on the drawing:
      1.   Soil Types: The boundaries of the various soil types occurring
within the subdivision with each type identified by both soil identification
number and name.
      2.   Soil Observation Points: The location of all soil observation pits.
      3.   Ground Water: The depth to ground water at each soil observation
point shall be as indicated.
      4.   Proposed Lots: The layout of the proposed subdivision as shown on
the preliminary plat or plan.
      5.   Topographical Survey: Existing topography as defined by Section
12-2-2 of this Title.
   F.   Site Characteristics: The plan shall locate and specify site
characteristics as follows:
      1.   Water Wells/ISD Systems: All existing water wells or individual
sewage disposal systems.
      2.   Waters Or Drainage: All existing streams, storm water runoff
channels, wetlands, surface waters, subsurface field tiles and the extent of
poorly drained areas or floodplain.
      3.   Storm Water Systems: All proposed storm water systems including
runoff channels, storm sewers, detention or retention areas and drain tile.
      4.   Roadways: Proposed roadways and other areas where existing soils
will be disturbed.
      5.   Wooded Areas: Heavily wooded areas or required conservancies.
   G.   Lot Specifications: The plan shall locate each proposed lot and shall
show the locations of the primary and expansion soil absorption areas thereon
and shall demonstrate the capacity of each lot to meet the requirements of this
Title.
   H.   Soil Maps And Soil Boring Logs: Soil maps and soil boring logs prepared
by a certified soil classifier must accompany the plan submittal. (Ord. 96-O-
16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 10
CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
12-10-1: General
12-10-2: Permit And License Requirements
12-10-3: Site Preparation
12-10-4: Fill
12-10-5: Excavation
12-10-6: Gravel
12-10-7: Piping
12-10-8: Backfilling
12-10-9: Accessories
12-10-10: Compliance
12-10-11: Administrative Procedures And Fees
12-10-1: GENERAL:
   A.   Manner Of Construction: Every individual sewage disposal system, once
approved, shall be constructed in a manner to preserve the condition of the
soil absorption area, and to promote the long-term sanitary treatment and
disposal of wastewater.
   B.   Inspections: The Enforcement Officer shall conduct inspections of
individual sewage disposal systems under construction to ensure compliance with
the requirements of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-2: PERMIT AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Construction Permit: No individual sewage disposal system shall be
constructed or repaired until a permit for its construction or repair has been
issued. An approved construction permit shall be posted on the site in a
prominent location.
      1.   Site Evaluation: The Enforcement Officer shall evaluate each site
prior to the issuance of the construction permit to ensure that the soil
absorption area has not been altered, that the soil absorption area is
protected by fencing, and that the information previously submitted and
approved is substantially unchanged.
      2.   Refusal To Issue Permit: The Enforcement Officer may refuse to issue
a construction permit where conditions on the site are inconsistent with the
approved plan, or where the soil absorption area is unprotected from
construction traffic by appropriate fencing. Where the issuance of a
construction permit is refused, the Enforcement Officer may require corrective
action or an initiation of the original approval process as appropriate.
   B.   Licensed Contractor: No person shall construct or repair an individual
sewage disposal system in the Village unless such person holds a valid private
sewage system installation contractor license in accordance with Chapter 12 of
this Title. The licensed contractor shall directly supervise all work conducted
on an individual sewage disposal system, and shall be responsible to ensure
that the work complies with this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-3: SITE PREPARATION:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Any preparation of the soil absorption area shall
be conducted only when the soil is dry. Site preparation shall be conducted
under the supervision of the licensed contractor as established in this
Section.
   B.   Mowed: All sites shall be mowed and cleared of brush.
   C.   Tree Removal: Any removal of trees shall be by cutting near the
surface. Stumps may be removed by grinding or cutting, but shall not be
uprooted.
   D.   Plow: Sites approved for ISD System Types 3, 4 and 5 shall be plowed
prior to the placement of fill or gravel as follows:
      1.   Equipment: Equipment shall be a chisel plow or mold board plow.
      2.   Contour: Plowing shall be done parallel to the site contour.
      3.   Tillage: Tillage shall be minimal to break the consistency of the
sod; maximum depth of tilling shall be eight inches (8") unless approved
otherwise.
      4.   After Tilling: After tilling, the site shall not be graded or
smoothed. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-4: FILL:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: The placement of fill material for ISD System
Types 3, 4 and 5 shall be as established in this Section.
   B.   Fill Specifications: Fill shall be approved coarse sand, except in the
Type 4 at-grade system where only gravel is required, but is handled and placed
in the same manner as fill material.
   C.   Fill Placement: The fill shall be placed according to the approved plan
and shall be placed immediately after site preparation.
   D.   Storage And Transportation: The storage and transportation of fill
shall be as specified on the approved plan; no traffic shall be allowed
directly on the plowed area.
   E.   Filling Procedure: Fill shall be placed only from the upslope or ends
of the proposed soil absorption area as follows:
      1.   Using Backhoe: Material may be placed with a backhoe reaching into
the soil absorption area.
      2.   Using Low Compression Equipment: Material may be pushed into the
soil absorption area by low compression equipment maintaining a minimum of ten
inches (10") of material beneath the equipment. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-5: EXCAVATION:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: The excavation for components and soil absorption
trenches shall be as established by this Section.
   B.   Components: Excavations for septic tanks, pretreatment units, lift
stations, sewer lines, header lines, pressure supply lines and other system
components other than soil absorption trenches shall be as follows:
      1.   Appropriate Elevations Or Overcut: Excavations shall be made to the
appropriate elevation or overcut only to accommodate bedding material.
      2.   Grading: Excavations shall be level or uniformly graded as
appropriate so that tanks, containers, and piping is supported and secure.
      3.   Slope: Excavations for piping shall be uniformly sloped so that
wastewater does not pond in bowed areas.
   C.   Trench Excavation: Excavation for soil absorption trenches or beds
shall be as follows:
      1.   Site Contour: Excavation shall be uniformly along the site contour,
not exceeding the depth specified on the approved plan.
      2.   Bottom Surface: The trench or bed shall be excavated with a level
bottom surface.
      3.   Compaction And/Or Smearing Protection: Excavation shall be done so
as to preserve the infiltrative trench or bed bottom and sidewalls from
compaction and/or smearing. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-6: GRAVEL:
   A.   Minimum Regulations: Gravel shall be placed in soil absorption trenches
as follows:
   B.   Gravel Depth: The depth of gravel specified below the distribution pipe
shall be reasonably level.
   C.   Placement: The gravel shall be placed carefully to avoid compaction of
the infiltrative surface.
   D.   Gravel/Piping: Gravel shall be placed around the distribution piping
and covering the piping a minimum of two inches (2").
   E.   Covering: The top of gravel in any soil absorption system shall be
covered with geotextile prior to backfilling. Other approved barrier materials,
such as untreated building paper or straw, may be employed except where
geotextile is specifically required by Section
12-7-3 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-7: PIPING:
   A.   Minimum Standards: All piping installed for individual sewage disposal
systems shall be uniformly supported, sloped as appropriate, and otherwise
installed as established in this Section.
   B.   Building Sewers: Building sewers shall be sloped not less than one-
eighth inch (1/8") per foot nor more than one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot for
ten feet (10') of the sewer preceding the pretreatment unit connection.
   C.   Connections: All piping shall be connected, solvent joined, or attached
with an appropriate adapter as acceptable for the material to ensure that
connections do not separate or allow the leakage of wastewater or infiltration
of groundwater.
   D.   Sealing: Piping entering or exiting septic tanks, pretreatment units,
lift stations, distribution devices, or other component not equipped with a
watertight connection shall be sealed.
   E.   Pressure Pipe Connections: Pipe connectors and fittings on pressure
supply lines, manifolds, or lateral distribution pipes shall be pressure
connectors or fittings.
   F.   Distribution Boxes: Pipe directly connected to distribution boxes shall
be rigid, noncorrugated, nonperforated pipe extending into the absorption area
as specified by subsection 12-7-3B1 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-8: BACKFILLING:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Backfilling operations shall be conducted as
established by this Section. Backfill material shall meet the specifications
established by Section
12-11-8 of this Title.
   B.   Weather Conditions: Backfill material shall not be frozen or wet.
   C.   Timing: Backfilling and covering shall be completed as soon as
practical.
   D.   Drainage: Backfilling and covering shall direct storm water away from
system components and the soil absorption area.
   E.   Placement Around Components: Backfill for excavations of tanks,
distribution devices, piping, etc., shall be carefully placed to avoid
displacing the components. The backfill material shall be tamped or compacted
to secure the components, minimize settling, and prevent wastewater seepage
along excavations.
   F.   Placement In Soil Absorption Area: Backfill and/or cover for soil
absorption areas shall be carefully placed to avoid displacing the barrier
material.
   G.   Equipment Traffic: The backfill or cover shall be placed with a minimum
of equipment traffic.
   H.   Expansion Areas: No traffic shall be allowed on downslope areas or
expansion areas. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-9: ACCESSORIES:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Devices and piping employed for the distribution
of wastewater into the soil absorption area or regulating the flow of
wastewater shall be constructed, installed or equipped as established by this
Section.
   B.   Equal Flow Distribution Box: Where an equal flow distribution box is
employed to direct wastewater flow to two (2) or more wastewater absorption
pipes, the invert elevation of all outflow pipes shall be leveled with a
premanufactured cap specifically designed to adjust the flowline of
distribution box piping.
   C.   Perforations: Perforations drilled into low pressure pipe wastewater
distribution lines shall be carefully placed along a straight line and drilled
at a perpendicular angle to the apex of the pipe.
   D.   Other Components: Diversion valves, flow control valves, effluent
filters or any other component which is located outside of a septic tank or
similar containment shall be provided with access to final grade sufficient to
allow applicable adjustment or maintenance as required.
   E.   Lift Station Pumps: Lift station pumps shall be placed at least six
inches (6") above the floor of the lift station. Float switches shall be
secured to the vertical piping with corrosion- resistant straps or ties. All
pumps shall be provided with a threaded coupling or other disconnecting
fitting, and shall be provided with a corrosion-resistant rope, strap or other
device for removing the pump.
   F.   Audio-Visual Alarm: Pumps, aerobic units, or other mechanical system
shall be provided with an audio-visual alarm. Electrical wiring and connections
shall conform to applicable standards. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-10: COMPLIANCE:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: No individual sewage disposal system or part
thereof shall be backfilled until the system has been inspected and approved.
Any part that has been covered before inspection and approval shall be
uncovered as required by the Enforcement Officer.
   B.   Inspections: The Enforcement Officer shall make inspections of the
construction of individual sewage disposal systems to ensure compliance with
the requirements of this Title.
   C.   Required Inspections: Inspections shall be requested by the licensed
contractor as follows:
      1.   Site Preparation: Inspection of the plowed surface of the soil
absorption area.
      2.   System: Inspection of completed system prior to backfill or cover,
of low pressure pipe prior to gravel cover, and other components as necessary.
      3.   Final: Inspection of final grading, pressure tests of low pressure
systems, floor plan, clean water discharges, see accessories, and other items
as necessary.
   D.   Other Inspections: The Enforcement Officer may require or conduct any
other inspections as may be necessary.
   E.   Covering System: No portion of the system shall be covered until
approved by the Enforcement Officer. The Enforcement Officer, after
identification, shall have access to the property at any reasonable time for
the purpose of conducting inspections.
   F.   Nonconforming Parts: Where inspection discloses defective material or
unworkmanlike construction which does not conform to the requirements of this
Title, the nonconforming parts shall be removed, replaced and reinspected.
   G.   Final Approval: No individual sewage disposal system shall be placed
into service without the final approval of the Enforcement Officer. (Ord. 96-O-
16, 12-17-1996)
12-10-11: ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES AND FEES:
Administrative procedures and fees relative to this Chapter shall be in
accordance with Chapter 16 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 11
MATERIALS
SECTION:
12-11-1: General
12-11-2: Pretreatment Components
12-11-3: Lift Stations
12-11-4: Distribution Devices
12-11-5: Valves
12-11-6: Piping
12-11-7: Fill/Aggregate
12-11-8: Backfill Material
12-11-9: Items Not Specified; Other Materials
12-11-1: GENERAL:
   A.   Minimum Standards: All materials employed in the construction or repair
of individual sewage disposal systems shall be to the specifications of this
Title to minimize maintenance, repair, or replacement and to promote the long-
term treatment and disposal of wastewater. Specifications detailed in this
Chapter shall be minimum standards.
   B.   Approval: All materials, equipment and devices approved for use shall
be constructed and installed in accordance with such approval.
      1.   Reconditioning: The Enforcement Officer shall have the right to
approve used materials, equipment and devices provided that such materials and
equipment have been reconditioned, tested and placed in working condition. No
reconditioned materials or equipment may be employed in Class I aerobic units.
      2.   Technical Data: The Enforcement Officer may require that sufficient
technical data be submitted to substantiate the proposed use of any material or
assembly, and if it is determined that the evidence submitted is satisfactory
proof of performance for the use intended, the Enforcement Officer shall
approve its use subject to the requirements of this Title. The costs of all
tests, reports and investigations required under these provisions shall be paid
by the applicant. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-2: PRETREATMENT COMPONENTS:
   A.   Septic Tanks: Any septic tank employed in the construction or repair of
an individual sewage disposal system shall meet the minimum standards for
construction established in the Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act
and Code.
   B.   Aerobic Units: Any aerobic unit employed in the construction or repair
of an individual sewage disposal system, whether discharging into a soil
absorption system or the surface, shall be certified by NSF International as a
Class I unit.
   C.   Effluent Filters: Any effluent filter employed in the construction or
repair of an individual sewage disposal system shall be designed for the
specific purpose of filtering septic tank effluent, shall be effective in the
reduction of BOD5 and total suspended solids, and shall be easily maintained.
(Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-3: LIFT STATIONS:
   A.   General: Any lift station employed in the construction or repair of an
individual sewage disposal system shall be watertight and shall be designed to
prevent flotation when emptied.
   B.   Risers: Every lift station shall be equipped with a riser extending a
minimum of four inches (4") above grade covered with a lid secured to prevent
unauthorized entry.
   C.   Pumps And Controls: Any pump employed in the construction or repair of
an individual sewage disposal system shall be specified by its manufacturer as
an effluent or sewage pump. Pumps shall be nonautomatic, operated by an
external switch or control.
      1.   Pump Switches: Pump switches shall be sealed mercury float switches
or equal. Any pump employed in a low pressure pipe see shall be controlled by
dual switches to accurately regulate pumping volume.
      2.   Pump Controls: Pump controls, if employed, shall be operated by
mercury float switches or equal. Duplex controls shall be wired as three (3)
float, alternating cycles.
      3.   Electrical Boxes: Electrical boxes shall be watertight and located
outside of the pump tank.
      4.   Timing: No pump shall be operated by a timing mechanism unless
specifically proposed and approved for the individual circumstance. (Ord. 96-O-
16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-4: DISTRIBUTION DEVICES:
Any distribution boxes employed in the construction or repair of an individual
sewage disposal system shall be constructed of concrete or plastic. (Ord. 96-O-
16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-5: VALVES:
   A.   General: Any valve employed in the construction or repair of an
individual sewage disposal system shall be as established by this Section.
   B.   Diversion Valves: Diversion valves shall be PVC and shall be designed
with one inlet dividing flow into either of two (2) or more outlets, and be
operated by a single valve control.
   C.   Ball Or Gate Valves: Ball valves or gate valves in low pressure pipe
systems shall be PVC.
   D.   Check Valves: Check valves, where required, shall be PVC solvent joined
or compression fitting. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-6: PIPING:
   A.   General: Any piping employed in the construction or repair of an
individual sewage disposal system shall be as established by this Section or an
equivalent for the intended use as specified in the Illinois Private Sewage
Disposal Code, section 905, appendix A, illustration C.
   B.   Building Sewers: Building sewers shall be Schedule 40 PVC or equal,
four inches (4") or greater in diameter.
   C.   Gravity Effluent Lines: Gravity effluent lines shall be SDR 35 PVC or
equal, four inches (4") in diameter.
   D.   Pressure Supply Lines: Pressure supply lines shall be SDR 21 PVC or
equal, and
      1.   LPP Systems: Two inch (2") minimum diameter on low pressure pipe
systems.
      2.   Distribution Boxes: one and one-half inch (11/2") minimum diameter
to distribution boxes.
   E.   Low Pressure Lateral Piping: Low pressure pipe lateral distribution
piping shall be SDR 26 PVC or equal and one and one- fourth inch (11/4")
minimum diameter.
   F.   Gravity Lateral Piping: Gravity lateral distribution piping shall be
corrugated polyethylene ASTM Standard F667-84 or equal and four inch (4")
minimum diameter.
   G.   Appropriate Size And Material: Couplings, connectors and fittings shall
be as appropriate for the size, material and use.
   H.   Pressure Lines Or Low Pressure Pipe Systems: All fittings in pressure
lines or low pressure pipe systems shall be schedule 40 PVC or equal pressure
fittings. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-7: FILL/AGGREGATE:
   A.   Fill Material: Any fill material employed in the construction or repair
of an individual sewage disposal soil absorption system shall be coarse sand.
   B.   Gravel: Any gravel employed in the construction or repair of an
individual sewage disposal system shall be sized between three-fourths inch (3/
4") and one and one-half inches (11/2"), and shall be washed to be essentially
free of dust, sand or other material.
   C.   Barrier Material: Any material employed in the construction or repair
of an individual sewage disposal system to separate gravel from backfill or
cover soil shall be an approved biodegradable material, such as untreated
building paper or an appropriate geotextile. Barrier material for ISD System
Types 4 and 5 shall be an appropriate geotextile only. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-
1996)
12-11-8: BACKFILL MATERIAL:
Any soil material used in backfilling or covering individual sewage disposal
system components or soil absorption areas shall be free of rocks, clods and
extraneous materials, of a suitable quality to support vegetative cover, and
requiring a minimum of landscaping. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-11-9: ITEMS NOT SPECIFIED; OTHER MATERIALS:
Any material employed in the construction or repair of an individual sewage
disposal system which is not specified in this Section shall be approved only
after a review of the proposed usage by the Enforcement Officer. (Ord. 96-O-16,
12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 12
LICENSING AND CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
12-12-1: Authority
12-12-2: Soil Classifiers
12-12-3: Individual Sewage Disposal System Designs
12-12-4: Individual Sewage Disposal System Contractors
12-12-5: Individual Sewage Disposal System Pumpers
12-12-1: AUTHORITY:
The Enforcement Officer shall regulate the evaluation of soils and the design,
construction, and pumping of individual sewage disposal systems in the Village
by requiring any individual who would evaluate soils or design, construct, or
pump an individual sewage disposal system to meet licensing or certification
requirements. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-12-2: SOIL CLASSIFIERS:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Any person who would evaluate soils for an
individual sewage disposal system shall be knowledgeable of the methods and
principles of soil classification and experienced in determining the formation,
morphology and description of soils and their applicable characteristics.
   B.   Credentials: The Village shall require soil classifiers to possess
certification by either the Illinois Soil Classifiers Association or the
American Registry of Certified Professionals in Agronomy, Crops, and Soils.
(Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-12-3: INDIVIDUAL SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM DESIGNS:
   A.   Professional Engineer: Design of an individual sewage disposal system
shall be by an Illinois licensed professional engineer knowledgeable of the
rules and regulations of the State, the County, the Village and of the general
provisions of the materials incorporated by Appendix A of this Title.
   B.   Installation Contractor: Plans for the repair, replacement or addition
of system components other than soil absorption capacity shall be prepared by
an Illinois licensed private sewage system installation contractor or an
Illinois licensed professional engineer. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-12-4: INDIVIDUAL SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM CONTRACTORS:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Any person who would construct, install, or
repair an individual sewage disposal system shall be knowledgeable of the
construction procedures specified herein, and of the interpretation of plans,
drawings, and specifications relative to the construction of an individual
sewage disposal system and shall be licensed as specified in subsection B of
this Section.
   B.   License: Sewage system installation contractors installing,
constructing or repairing an individual sewage disposal system within the
Village shall possess a valid license issued by the Illinois Department of
Public Health. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-12-5: INDIVIDUAL SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM PUMPERS:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: Any person who would clean or pump waste from a
private sewage disposal system or portable toilet or haul or dispose of wastes
removed therefrom shall be knowledgeable of the requirements of Chapter 13 of
this Title and shall be licensed as specified in subsection B of this Section.
   B.   License: Private sewage disposal pumping contractors operating within
the Village shall possess a valid license issued by the Illinois Department of
Public Health. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 13
WASTE HAULERS AND SEPTAGE DISPOSAL
SECTION:
12-13-1: Minimum Requirements
12-13-2: Land Application Prohibited
12-13-3: Site Management
12-13-4: Equipment
12-13-5: Inspections
12-13-6: Reporting Requirements
12-13-7: Other Requirements
12-13-8: Administrative Procedures And Fees
12-13-1: MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
Domestic septage may be disposed of only by methods established in this
Section:
   A.   Sewage Treatment Facility: Septage may be disposed of at a sewage
treatment plant appropriately licensed to operate by the Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency.
   B.   Landfill: Septage may be disposed of at a landfill appropriately
permitted to operate and to accept the material by the Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency.
   C.   Application To Agricultural Land: Septage may be applied to
agricultural land only as specifically established in this Chapter.
   D.   Other Approved Methods: Septage may be disposed of by other methods
subject to the approval of that method by the Illinois Environmental Protection
Agency and the Illinois Department of Public Health. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-2: LAND APPLICATION PROHIBITED:
   A.   General: Septage shall not be land-applied on any site within the
Village except pursuant to a variation approved by ordinance of the President
and Board of Trustees.
      1.   Permit: Sites approved for land application of septage by variation
ordinance shall also receive a permit from the Enforcement Officer.
      2.   Permit Renewal: Permits issued for septage land application sites
shall expire on December 31 of each year, and must be renewed.
      3.   Permit Suspension: The Enforcement Officer may suspend for good
cause the permit of any septage land application site. Any appeal of such
suspension and any penalty for continued use of a site after permit suspension
shall be established by this Title.
   B.   Approval Conditions: Any site submitted for approval as a septage land
application site by variation ordinance shall meet the standard required for
variations as required by this Title as well as minimum standards as
established by this Section.
      1.   Notification: No site may be approved for septage land application
without a variation approved by ordinance of the President and Board of
Trustees of the Village and the written approval of the Enforcement Officer.
      2.   Limiting Layer: Septage shall not be applied on land having a
limiting layer within four feet (4') of the soil surface.
      3.   Floodplain/Surface Water: Sites proposed for septage land
application shall be above floodplain elevation, and shall be separated from
surface waters and/or wetlands as provided below.
      4.   Slope: Sites proposed for septage land application shall be sloped a
maximum of five percent (5%).
      5.   Separation Requirements: Any areas designated for septage land
application shall be separated as established by this subsection.
         a.   Water Wells: Application area shall be a minimum of three hundred
feet (300') from any water well.
         b.   Public Roads: Application areas shall be a minimum of one hundred
feet (100') from any public road right of way.
         c.   Residential, Commercial Or Industrial Areas: Application areas
shall be a minimum of one thousand four hundred feet (1,400') from areas
regularly populated or utilized by humans.
         d.   Surface Waters: Application areas shall be a minimum of two
hundred feet (200') from any surface water, wetland, drainage ditch, or surface
inlet to subsurface drains. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-3: SITE MANAGEMENT:
   A.   Site Posted: Any septage land application site shall be appropriately
posted when there is potential for public access.
   B.   Ponding: Septage shall not be applied where water is ponded in the land
application area.
   C.   Pooling: Septage shall be evenly spread over the application areas to
prevent pooling.
   D.   Rainfall: Septage shall not be applied to a site which has been
saturated by rainfall during the twenty four (24) hour period preceding the
intended application time.
   E.   Application Rates: The cumulation volume of septage applied per year
shall not exceed the nitrogen requirements of the cover crop.
      1.   Cover Crop: A cover crop must be established on land application
sites prior to the first application of septage, even where the crop is not
intended for harvest.
   F.   Vegetation Restricted: The use of a septage application site for
vegetation shall be restricted.
      1.   Vegetables And Fruits: The cultivation of root vegetables or other
low-growing fruits or vegetables on septage disposal sites is prohibited.
      2.   Pasture: Pasture utilized for septage application shall be
restricted from harvest or animal grazing for a minimum of thirty (30) days
following septage application.
   G.   Spillage: Septage shall be transported and land-applied in such a
manner as to prevent spillage of wastes or the deposition of wastes or mud onto
any public road or right of way.
   H.   Soil Incorporation: When conditions exist at a septage land application
site which are determined by the Enforcement Officer to be a nuisance, septage
shall be appropriately incorporated into the soil after application.
   I.   Soil Injection And Tillage: If septage is injected or tilled into the
soil throughout the growing season as a method of pathogen control, application
must be done on a rotational basis within the site to maintain vegetative
growth. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-4: EQUIPMENT:
   A.   General: Any vehicle used for the collection and transportation of
septage shall be properly equipped and maintained as established by this
Section.
   B.   Container: Vehicle tanks shall be completely enclosed and leak-free.
   C.   Pump: Septage pumps shall be vacuum or self-priming and shall be leak-
free.
   D.   Hoses: Septage hoses shall be leak-free, and stored in such a manner
that contamination will not create a health risk or nuisance.
   E.   Discharge Nozzle: Septage tank discharge nozzles shall be located in
such a manner that discharging waste does not flow or drip onto the vehicle,
and shall be capped when not in use.
   F.   Equipment Condition: All equipment utilized in the pumping, storage,
hauling and land application of septage shall be kept reasonably clean and in
good working condition.
   G.   Vehicle Identification: The name and address of the septage hauling
business shall be displayed in eight inch (8") letters on both sides of any
septage hauling vehicle. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-5: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Land Application Sites: The Enforcement Officer shall inspect any site
utilized for the land application of septage for compliance with this Chapter
not less often than two (2) times per year.
   B.   Vehicles And Equipment: The Enforcement Officer shall inspect any
vehicle utilized for the pumping and hauling of septage for compliance with
this Chapter not less often than once per year.
   C.   Enforcement: The Enforcement Officer may issue notices and orders
requiring action as may be necessary to assure compliance with this Chapter.
(Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-6: REPORTING REQUIREMENTS:
On a quarterly basis, licensed pumpers land-applying septage must report the
following information:
   A.   Volume of septage land-applied each month during the quarter.
   B.   Acreage treated each month during the quarter.
   C.   Site map showing area of application for each month during the quarter.
   D.   Signature. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-7: OTHER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   County, State And Federal Regulations: The requirements established by
this Chapter shall in no way preclude compliance with any applicable County,
State or Federal regulation.
   B.   Conflict: Whenever the provisions of this Chapter conflict with any of
the provisions of any other applicable ordinance, regulation or rule, the most
stringent requirement shall be applicable. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-13-8: ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES AND FEES:
Administrative procedure and fees relative to this Chapter shall be in
accordance with Chapter 16 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 14
MAINTENANCE
SECTION:
12-14-1: Agreement
12-14-2: Aerobic Unit
12-14-3: Surface Discharge
12-14-4: Holding Tanks
12-14-5: Contingency Systems
12-14-6: Nonconforming/Experimental Systems
12-14-7: Disclosure
12-14-8: Reporting
12-14-9: Procedures
12-14-1: AGREEMENT:
The Enforcement Officer shall require that the owner of record of an individual
sewage disposal system initiate and keep in force an agreement for inspection
and maintenance of the individual sewage disposal system in accordance with
this Chapter, and that the owner take action to repair, replace, modify, or
maintain an individual sewage disposal system when necessary to ensure its
proper operation. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-2: AEROBIC UNIT:
   A.   Agreement: The owner of record of any individual sewage disposal system
which employs an aerobic unit for pretreatment of wastewater shall initiate and
keep in force an agreement for inspection and maintenance of the aerobic unit
with an authorized representative of the manufacturer.
   B.   Inspections: The agreement shall provide for inspections of the aerobic
unit a minimum of two (2) times per year, and shall provide for the repair,
replacement, adjustment or modification of the aerobic unit and for additional
inspections as are necessary to ensure the proper operation of the unit. (Ord.
96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-3: SURFACE DISCHARGE:
   A.   Agreement: The owner of record of any system which is approved pursuant
to subsection 12-8-4C of this Title to discharge effluent to the surface shall
initiate and keep in force an agreement for inspection and maintenance of the
system as required in this Section:
      1.   Aerobic Unit: Any surface discharging system which employs an
aerobic unit shall be maintained in accordance with Section
12-14-2 of this Chapter and further as specified in this Section.
      2.   System Inspection: Any surface discharging system which does not
employ an aerobic unit shall be covered by an agreement with a licensed private
sewage system installation contractor which shall provide for inspection of the
system a minimum of two (2) times per year, and shall provide for the repairs,
replacement, adjustment or modification to the system as is necessary to ensure
proper operation.
      3.   Effluent Discharge: Any surface discharging system shall have, as a
provision of the required maintenance agreement, its effluent discharge sampled
a minimum of two (2) times per year. Samples shall be analyzed in accordance
with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" for
compliance to the following standards:
         a.   BOD5 less than 30 mg/l.
         b.   Total suspended solids less than 30 mg/l.
         c.   Fecal coliform less than 400 organism/100 ml.
         d.   No detectable odor or floating debris.
         e.   Chlorine residual. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-4: HOLDING TANKS:
   A.   Agreement: The owner of record of any holding tank which is approved
shall initiate and keep in force an agreement for inspection and maintenance of
the holding tank with a licensed private sewage disposal system pumping
contractor. The agreement shall provide for the continuous pumping of
wastewater from the holding tank as is necessary, and for the repair,
replacement, adjustment or modification of the holding tank or associated
appurtenances as is necessary to ensure the proper operation of the unit. (Ord.
96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-5: CONTINGENCY SYSTEMS:
   A.   Agreement: The owner of record of any contingency system approved
pursuant to subsection 12-8-3A of this Title shall initiate and keep in force
an agreement for inspection and maintenance of the system with a licensed
private sewage system installation contractor. The agreement shall provide for
inspection of the system and the alternation of soil absorption systems a
minimum of one time per year, and shall provide for the repair, replacement,
adjustment or modification of the system as is necessary to ensure proper
operation. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-6: NONCONFORMING/EXPERIMENTAL SYSTEMS:
   A.   Agreement: The owner of record of any nonconforming or experimental
system approved pursuant to Section
12-5-5 or subsection 12-8-4C of this Title, respectively, shall initiate and
keep in force an agreement for the inspection and maintenance of the system as
specifically determined by the Enforcement Officer conditional to the approval.
(Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-7: DISCLOSURE:
   A.   Agreement: Any requirement for a maintenance agreement, as specified by
this Section or by any variation or decision on appeal, shall be recorded with
the Lake County Recorder of Deeds as a covenant agreement between the Village
and the owner of record of the individual sewage disposal system. (Ord. 96-O-
16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-8: REPORTING:
   A.   Requirements: Maintenance activities conducted on individual sewage
disposal systems subject to the requirements of this Section shall be reported
as outlined in this Section.
   B.   Maintenance Or Sampling Activity: The owner of record of an individual
sewage disposal system subject to the maintenance requirements specified in
this Section shall submit to the Enforcement Officer a report of all required
maintenance or sampling activity established herein or by any other agreement
conditional to the initial approval, the repair, or the use of the individual
sewage disposal system.
      1.   Reports: Reports shall be submitted in a timely fashion at intervals
established by this Section, excepting that reports relative to pumping holding
tanks shall be submitted not less than every three (3) months.
   C.   Additional Reports: Maintenance contractors shall submit to the
Enforcement Officer additional reports as follows:
      1.   Maintenance Activity: A report of maintenance activity which
includes the repair, replacement, modification, or adjustment of an individual
sewage disposal system or component where necessary to ensure its proper
operation.
      2.   Malfunction: A report of an observed malfunction of an individual
sewage disposal system contracted for maintenance where the malfunction allows
effluent which is or may be inadequately treated to discharge to the ground
surface or to a surface water.
      3.   Contract Cancellation Or Nonrenewal: A report of a cancellation or
failure to renew an established maintenance contract, or a refusal of an owner
of an individual sewage disposal system to undertake necessary repair,
replacement, modification, or adjustment to the system.
      4.   Pumping Activity: A report of each pumping of a permanent or
temporary holding tank.
   D.   Reporting Requirements: Reports shall be submitted in a timely fashion,
excepting that a report of a discharge of inadequately treated effluent to the
ground surface or a surface water shall be reported within twenty four (24)
hours.
      1.   Form Specifications: Any report submitted to the Enforcement Officer
as required by this Section shall include, as a minimum, the name of the owner
of record, a complete mailing address, a complete legal description, the
permanent index number (PIN) and the individual sewage disposal system permit
number. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-14-9: PROCEDURES:
Administrative procedure and fees relative to this Section shall be in
accordance with Chapter 16 of this Title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 15
ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
12-15-1: Violations (Rep. by Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-15-2: Notice Of Violation
12-15-3: Emergencies
12-15-4: Revocation Of Approval
12-15-5: Variances
12-15-6: Hearings On Variations And Appeals
12-15-7: Application After Revocation
12-15-1: VIOLATIONS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-15-2: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
   A.   Requirements: Whenever the enforcement officer determines that there
are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any
provision of this title, the owner or beneficial owner of the property, the
occupant(s) of the premises, and/or the person to whom the permit was issued,
shall be notified of such alleged violation, as herein provided. Such notice
shall:
      1.   Be in writing.
      2.   Include a statement of the reasons for the issuance of the notice.
      3.   Allow reasonable time as determined by the enforcement officer for
the performance of any act it requires.
      4.   Be served upon the owner, operator, or permit holder as the case may
require; provided that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been
properly served upon such owner, operator or permit holder when a copy thereof
has been sent by certified or registered mail to his last known address; or,
when he has been served with such notice by any other method authorized by the
laws of the state; and
      5.   Contain an outline of remedial action which is required to effect
compliance with this title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-15-3: EMERGENCIES:
Whenever an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the
public safety or health, the enforcement officer may, without any
administrative procedure and without notice of hearing, seek a temporary
restraining order or an injunction to require that such action be taken as may
be necessary to meet the emergency or to obtain compliance with this title.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, such order shall be
effective immediately. When such emergency conditions are abated, the
enforcement officer may request the court to enter an order dissolving the
temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-
1996)
12-15-4: REVOCATION OF APPROVAL:
   A.   Site Conditions: Whenever the condition of a site approved for an
individual sewage disposal system has changed or any information considered in
the approval of an individual sewage disposal system was omitted or erroneous,
the enforcement officer may revoke the approval of that site and of any
construction permit issued pursuant to the approval.
   B.   Revocation Notice: Revocation of approval shall be in writing, posted
at the site and mailed to the owner, professional engineer, and licensed
contractor, as applicable, by certified or registered mail. The notice shall
contain information as follows:
      1.   A statement that work on the individual sewage disposal system is
prohibited.
      2.   An explanation of the reason for the revocation of approval.
      3.   An outline of action required toward the reinstatement of the
approval, if determined.
      4.   An explanation of rights and procedures for a hearing on an appeal
as provided in sections
12-15-6 and
12-15-7 of this chapter.
   C.   Request For Hearing: Unless the enforcement officer receives a request
for a hearing, the revocation of approval shall be considered as final. (Ord.
96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-15-5: VARIANCES:
   A.   Variance Requests: Whenever approval as required by this title is
denied by the enforcement officer, that person denied approval may request a
variance as follows:
      1.   Written Requests: Variance requests shall be in writing and shall
detail those conditions where compliance is impossible or impractical.
      2.   Supporting Data: Variance requests shall include pertinent data to
support the requested waiver of the requirements of this title as being
consistent with the purpose of this title to protect and provide for the
health, safety, and general welfare of the people of the village and of other
affected communities.
      3.   Variations: Variations, including the approval of contingency
systems as provided by chapter 8 of this title, shall only be granted by the
village board by ordinance, after a hearing as provided in section
12-15-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-15-6: HEARINGS ON VARIATIONS AND APPEALS:
   A.   Hearings: Any person who wishes to seek a variation from a specific
provision of this title or any person affected or aggrieved by any order,
notice or decision issued by the enforcement officer in connection with the
enforcement of any provision of this title may file with the village president
a written request for a hearing before the village board. The village board
shall hold a hearing within thirty (30) days from the date on which the written
request was filed. The petitioner for the hearing shall be notified of the time
and place of the hearing not less than five (5) days prior to the date on which
the hearing is to be held. If, as a result of the hearing, the village board
finds that strict compliance with the order, notice, decision, or a specific
provision or provisions of this title would cause undue hardship on the
petitioner, and that the public health would be adequately protected and
substantial justice done by varying or withdrawing the order, notice, decision,
or varying the application of a specific provision of this title, the village
board may modify or withdraw the order, or notice, or decision, or grant a
variation by ordinance, as the case may be, and, as a condition for such action
may, where it deems it necessary, make requirements which are in addition to
those prescribed in this title for the purpose of properly protecting the
public health. The village board shall render a decision within thirty (30)
days after the date of the hearing which shall be reduced to writing and placed
on file in the office of the village administrator as a matter of public
record.
   B.   Fee: A fee for a hearing on a variation or an appeal as specified from
time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code shall be submitted. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-15-7: APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION:
Whenever the revocation of the approval of an individual sewage disposal system
is final, any future consideration for approval shall be in accordance with
chapter 5 of this title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 16
PROCEDURES AND FEES
SECTION:
12-16-1: General
12-16-2: Individual Sewage Disposal Systems
12-16-3: Alterations And Additions
12-16-4: New Subdivisions
12-16-5: Soil Evaluations
12-16-6: Construction Permit
12-16-7: Other Permits And Services
12-16-8: Fee Schedule
12-16-1: GENERAL:
Procedures for the consideration of approval of proposed individual sewage
disposal systems, subdivisions, and alteration, for the conducting of soil
evaluations, for the consideration of variances, for hearings, for construction
permits, and for special maintenance and operational permits as detailed in
this title. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-16-2: INDIVIDUAL SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
   A.   Submission Of Plans: Any plan submitted for approval for the
construction or repair of an individual sewage disposal system shall be
submitted as outlined in this section.
      1.   Application: An application for approval shall be completed.
      2.   Fee: A fee as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code.
      3.   Required Information: Six (6) copies of a plan prepared in
accordance with section
12-9-2 or
12-9-3 of this title shall be submitted with any supplemental information as
required by section
12-9-4 of this title.
   B.   Plan Review: Upon receipt of an application, plans properly submitted
for approval, and receipt of the appropriate fee, the enforcement officer shall
review the application and plan for compliance with this title, and shall
approve or refuse to approve the application within fifteen (15) working days.
   C.   Notification Of Nonapproval: The enforcement officer shall notify any
applicant whose application is not approved of the reason(s) preventing the
approval and of any technical or administrative solution remaining.
   D.   Plan Approval Period: A plan approved for the construction of a new
individual sewage disposal system shall be valid for a period of twenty four
(24) months from the date of approval. A plan approved for the repair or
expansion of an existing sewage disposal system shall be valid for a period of
twelve (12) months from the date of approval. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-16-3: ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS:
   A.   General: Any proposal to alter, expand, remodel, or change usage of any
dwelling or establishment utilizing an existing individual sewage disposal
system submitted for approval in accordance with section
12-5-4 of this title shall be submitted as follows:
      1.   Increased Water Usage/Square Footage Increase Greater Than Fifty
Percent: Proposals which may increase water usage, which increase the square
footage of a dwelling or establishment by more than fifty percent (50%), or
which involve a change of use for a commercial establishment projecting an
increase in water usage shall be submitted and processed in accordance with
subsection 12-5-3A and section
12-9-2 of this title.
      2.   No Water Usage Increase/Square Footage Increase Less Than Fifty
Percent: Proposals which may not increase water usage or do not increase the
square footage of a dwelling by more than fifty percent (50%) shall be
submitted as follows:
         a.   Application: An application for approval shall be submitted.
         b.   Fees: A fee in accordance with section
12-16-8 of this chapter shall be submitted.
         c.   Required Information: Two (2) copies of a plan depicting the
existing site conditions, including the individual sewage disposal system,
water well, existing floor plan and the proposed alteration or addition shall
be submitted.
   B.   Plan Review: Upon receipt of an application, plans properly submitted
for approval, and receipt of the appropriate fee, the enforcement officer shall
review the application and plan for compliance with this title, and shall
approve or refuse to approve the application within fifteen (15) working days.
   C.   Notification Of Nonapproval: The enforcement officer shall notify any
applicant whose application is not approved of the reason(s) preventing the
approval and of any technical or administrative solution remaining.
   D.   Plan Approval Period: A plan approved for the construction or repair of
an individual sewage disposal system shall be valid for a period of twenty four
(24) months from the date of approval. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-16-4: NEW SUBDIVISIONS:
   A.   General: Any proposal for approval of a new subdivision in accordance
with section
12-5-6 of this title shall be submitted as follows:
      1.   Application: An application for approval shall be completed.
      2.   Fee: A fee as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code shall be submitted.
      3.   Plat: A preliminary plat or plan in accordance with section
12-9-5 of this title shall be submitted.
      4.   Additional Fees: Additional fees in accordance with other provisions
of this code and other ordinances of the village may be required.
   B.   Plan Review: The enforcement officer shall review plans for new
subdivisions within a reasonable time from the submittal, and shall correspond
with the applicant as necessary to effect changes toward compliance with this
title. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-16-5: SOIL EVALUATIONS:
   A.   General: Any proposal requesting a soil evaluation in accordance with
subsection 12-6-1C of this title shall be submitted as follows:
      1.   Application: An application for a soil evaluation shall be
completed.
      2.   Fee: A fee as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code shall be submitted.
   B.   Appointment: The enforcement officer shall schedule the date and time
of the soil evaluation within a period not to exceed fifteen (15) working days.
When weather conditions or frost greater than six inches (6") do not allow for
accurate soil descriptions, the soil test shall be postponed to allow for
acceptable conditions.
   C.   Soil Report: A report of the soil evaluation shall be mailed to the
applicant. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-16-6: CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
   A.   General: Any request for a permit to construct an individual sewage
disposal system submitted in accordance with subsection 12-10-2A of this title
shall be submitted.
   B.   Application: An application for a construction permit shall be
completed and submitted.
   C.   Fee: A fee as specified from time to time in section
1-10-7 of this code shall be submitted.
   D.   Revised Plan: A revision of the approved plan, if applicable, depicting
any changes to the plan or site shall be submitted.
   E.   Permit Review: Upon receipt of an application for a construction permit
and the appropriate fee, the enforcement officer shall review the application
and construction plan for compliance with this title and for substantial
agreement with the approved plan.
   F.   Notification Process: The enforcement officer shall issue or decline to
issue a construction permit within five (5) working days, and shall notify any
applicant whose permit is refused of the reason(s) preventing approval and of
any technical or administrative solution remaining.
   G.   Permit Period: The construction permit shall be valid for a period of
ninety (90) days from the date of approval. The enforcement officer may,
without additional fee, extend the construction permit for thirty (30) days
provided that such extension shall apply only to the licensed septic contractor
to whom the permit was originally issued. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
12-16-7: OTHER PERMITS AND SERVICES:
   A.   Procedural/Fee Requirements: The village enforcement officer shall
charge fees in accordance with section
12-16-8 of this chapter for other permits and services, including, but not
limited to, the following:
      1.   Nonconforming Systems: Review for approval of nonconforming systems
pursuant to subsection 12-5-5B of this title.
      2.   Site Drainage/Other Monitoring: Site visits to monitor site drainage
or for other monitoring.
      3.   Septage Disposal Sites: Site inspection of septage disposal sites if
a variation for same is granted.
      4.   Contingency Systems: Permits to use contingency systems, approved
pursuant to chapter 8 of this title.
      5.   Mandatory Maintenance Programs: Administration of mandatory
maintenance programs.
      6.   Soil Evaluation Review: Review of soil evaluations conducted by
certified soil classifiers. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-16-8: FEE SCHEDULE:
Fees as required by this title and this chapter shall be as specified from time
to time in section
1-10-7 of this code. (Ord. 2008-O-05, 2-5-2008)
CHAPTER 17
RELIEF FROM PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY
SECTION:
12-17-1: Personal Liability
12-17-1: PERSONAL LIABILITY:
The Enforcement Officer charged with the enforcement of this Title, while
acting for the jurisdiction, shall not thereby be liable personally, and is
hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to
persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the
discharge of official duties. Any suit instituted against any officer or
employee because of an act performed by the Enforcement Officer in the lawful
discharge of duties and under the provisions of this Title shall be defended by
the legal representative of the jurisdiction until the final termination of the
proceeding, except as may be otherwise required by statute. The Enforcement
Officer shall not be liable for costs in any action, suit, or proceedings that
may be instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this Title; any officer of
the Village shall be free from liability for acts performed under any of its
provisions or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of official
duties in connection therewith. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
CHAPTER 18
INTERPRETATION AND CONFLICT
SECTION:
12-18-1: Minimum Requirements
12-18-2: State And Local Requirements
12-18-1: MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
The provisions of this Title shall be held to be the minimum requirements for
the promotion of public health, safety and general welfare. Whenever a
provision, whether set forth in this Title or any other applicable provisions
of law, imposes overlapping or contradictory regulations or contains
restrictions covering similar subject matter, the provision which imposes
higher standards or requirements for the promotion of public health and safety
of the people of the Village shall prevail. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
12-18-2: STATE AND LOCAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Compliance: Compliance with this Title does not release applicant from
compliance with applicable State or County local ordinances or regulations
governing individual sewage disposal systems. (Ord. 96-O-16, 12-17-1996)
TITLE 13
WATER AND SEWERS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL
SECTION:
13-1-1: Water And Sewer Agreement
13-1-2: Mandatory Use Of Service
13-1-3: Definitions
13-1-4: Application For Service
13-1-5: Superintendent; Appointment And Duties
13-1-6: Conflicting Laws
13-1-1: WATER AND SEWER AGREEMENT:
Lake Barrington business and industrial park sanitary sewer system ("the LBBIP
sanitary sewer system") and the Lake Barrington business and industrial park
water system ("the LBBIP water system") shall be governed by the provisions of
this title and the intergovernmental agreement for wastewater treatment
services by and between the village of Fox River Grove and the village of Lake
Barrington. In case of conflict the terms of the intergovernmental agreement
shall prevail. (Ord. 98-O-07, 3-3-1998)
13-1-2: MANDATORY USE OF SERVICE:
   A.   All buildings intended or used for human habitation or occupancy and
all uses within the village's special service area number three must use and be
connected to the LBBIP ("Lake Barrington Business and Industrial Park") water
system and the LBBIP sanitary sewer system. The boundary limits of village of
Lake Barrington special service area number three are defined in section
13-1-3 of this chapter.
   B.   The owner and/or occupant of buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the village
of Lake Barrington's special service area number three as described above
shall, at his, her or its expense, connect such buildings and properties to the
LBBIP water system and to the LBBIP sanitary sewer system in accordance with
the provisions of this title, within sixty (60) days after the date official
notice to do so is mailed to them via regular mail and via certified mail,
return receipt requested.
   C.   Sixty (60) days after the date official notice has been given to the
owner and/or occupant of the premises to connect to the LBBIP water system and
LBBIP sanitary sewer system, it shall be unlawful to utilize any individual
sewage disposal system or any well, except any village wells and except any
well utilized by the village for purposes of monitoring the aquifer.
   D.   All individual wells, except any village wells and except any well
utilized by the village for purposes of monitoring the aquifer, and all
individual septic systems shall be properly abandoned within sixty (60) days
after said date on which said official notice has been given to the owner and/
or occupant. Such abandonment shall be in compliance with all applicable laws,
regulations, and ordinances of those governmental jurisdictions having
authority over same. (Ord. 2002-O-12, 8-6-2002)
13-1-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of the
following terms used in this title shall be as follows:
A: As in cyanide-A, means amenable to alkaline chlorination.
APPROVED: Backflow prevention devices or methods approved by the Research
Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern
California, American Water Works Association, American National Standards
Institute or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation or their
equivalent.
AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE OF USER: A. Principal executive officer of at least
the level of vice president, if the user is a corporation;
   B.   General partner or proprietor, if the user is a partnership or
proprietorship, respectively;
   C.   Duly authorized representative of the individual designated above. A
person is a duly authorized representative only if the authorization is made in
writing to the Village by a person described above.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the
premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water
supplied by the LBBIP water system. These auxiliary waters may include water
from another purveyor's public water supply system; or water from a source such
as wells, lakes, or streams, or process fluids; or used water. These waters may
be polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or
system over which the Village does not have control.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the
distribution pipes of the public water supply system or other potable water
system from any source other than the intended source of the potable water
supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of construction
intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system.
BASELINE MONITORING REPORT: The report required by 40 CFR section 403.12(b)
(1–7).
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen used in the biochemical
oxidation of organic matter in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade
(20°C), determined by standard laboratory test procedures and expressed in
milligrams per liter (mg/l).
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which
receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the
walls of a building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved
point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 m) outside the inner face of
the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal.
CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (COD): The quantity of oxygen consumed from a chemical
oxidant (standard potassium dichromate solution) under standard laboratory,
procedures, as described in standard methods.
COMBINED WASTE STREAM FORMULA: The formula as found in 40 CFR section 403.6(e).
COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT: A building or building complex which contains stores,
offices, recreational uses, or businesses engaged in trade, sales, and
services.
COMPATIBLE POLLUTANT: The biochemical oxygen demand, chemical oxygen demand,
suspended solids, fecal coliform bacteria and fats, oil or grease.
COMPOSITE SAMPLE: A sample of wastewater based on a flow proportional or time
proportional method.
CONSISTENT POTW TREATMENT WORKS REMOVAL, POLLUTANT REMOVAL, OR REMOVAL: The
reduction in the amount of a pollutant or alteration of the nature or
concentration of a pollutant in the influent of the POTW to a less incompatible
or less concentrated state in the effluent. Consistent POTW removal efficiency
shall be the difference between the average concentration of the pollutant in
the influent of the treatment plant and the average concentration of the
pollutant in the effluent of the treatment plant divided by the average
concentration of pollutant in the influent.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any
premises supplied by or in any manner connected to the public water supply
system.
CONSUMER'S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system located on the customer's premises. A
building plumbing system is considered to be a customer's water system.
CONTAMINANT: Any solid, liquid, or gaseous matter, any odor or any form of
energy which, when present in the public water supply system, may cause the
water to degrade so that the applicable water quality standards are not met or
physical illness or injury to persons consuming the water could result.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of water by entrance of any
substance to a degree which could create a health hazard.
CONTROL MANHOLE: A structure specifically designed and constructed for sampling
and metering industrial wastes discharged to a public sewer.
COOLING WATER: The water discharged from any use, such as air conditioning,
cooling, or refrigeration, to which the only pollutant added is heat.
CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICE INSPECTOR OR CCCDI: A person who has
successfully completed IEPA sponsored training and certification to install and
test backflow devices.
DIRECTOR: The director of the IEPA.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single, independently
acting check valves approved under or meeting the requirements of ASSE Standard
1015. A double check valve assembly must include tight shut-off valves located
at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing the water
tightness of each check valve.
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The Superintendent for the Village of Lake Barrington
shall serve as the enforcement officer for this Title of the Municipal Code.
EXISTING SOURCE: Any building, structure, facility or installation from which
there is or may be a discharge which is not a new source.
FATS, OIL OR GREASE: Any hydrocarbons, fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, oils
and any other material that is extracted by trichlorotrifluoroethane solvent.
FECAL COLIFORM: Any number of organisms common to the intestinal tract of man
and animals whose presence in water is an indicator of pollution.
FEDERAL ACT OR ACT: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 USC 1251 et
seq.) as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of Amendments of
1972 (Public Law 92-500 and Public Law 93-243) and the Clean Water Act of 1977
(Public Law 95-217).
FIXED PROPER AIR GAP OR AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the
free atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of
the receptacle. Flexible couplings or spring hoses do not constitute an air
gap.
FLOW: The volume of wastewater per unit of time.
FOX RIVER GROVE: The village of Fox River Grove, the owner and operator of the
POTW.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and
